column2: angry baby, 3-6 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: My 5yr old son has numerous struggles including insomnia, mood disorder, possible autism and much more. He rarely slept more than a few hrs off and on through the night and had up to 10 violent tantrums harming himself and others. I am not a believer of too many meds but as a single mom of 2 boys, I was at my wits ends. The 1st week he started on 1/2 a 25mg and did sleep better w/ decreased tantrums but them went to 25mg. For 3weeks my baby was extra hyper but tantrum free. Recently the meds started wearing off around 2pm and I can now expect several tantrums until he recieves his next dose at 9pm but his doc will probably increase at out next visit. It took almost 5 years of screaming and hitting and more than most could imagine but we finally have some peace in our home. And for the 1st time in as long as I can remember- my baby gave me a hug and kiss and told me he loved me after a few days of being on this med. Tears of happiness don't come too often. Of course he has had some side affects that we are monitoring; extreme thirst and monitoring sugar, increased appitite ( which he is already being tested for that before the meds)

column2: tresvick, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is a horrible medicine and I believe it should only be used as a last-ditch effort. At first it was a medication for severe psychotic disorders. Now it seems to be used as a catch-all for any type of depression or behavior problems. Even a small dosage can have lasting side effects, especially uncontrolled body movements and tics in different parts of your body that may or may not go away. My first experience with it caused my neck to move involuntarily in stiff movements. My next doctor ignored my reaction and gave me a low dosage of this drug. The first night after taking it, I couldn't walk straight; the second night my knee started to click when I walked; the third night my ankles started to click; the last night my neck started to crick or pop every time I moved it. That was the last night I took it and it took a year for my neck to stop clicking when I moved it. Even after that, my doctor ordered refills for me. I didn't take them and stopped seeing that doctor. I think you really need to be careful and if a medication is causing you unusual reactions, stop taking it and tell your doctor. If he won't listen, stop taking the medication and find another doctor who will listen to you and work with you to fing a medication that will help you instead of turning a psychotic medication for a non-psychotic condition.

column2: damien712, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed Seroquel in August of 2009. The medication was initially started at 100mg each day and titrated over a few weeks up to 500 mgs which is my current does. I have been suffering depression and anxiety for 30 years and have taken many different antidepressants. Nothing has even come close to helping my condition as much as Seroquel. I have been diagnosed with bipolar type 2 rapid cycling. Before Seroquel I would shift every month . Now I may have 3 or 4 short episodes of depression. As far as hypomania it really has not been much of a problem. Certain medications can cause me to shift to hypomania. For instance too much Nuvigal will do that. However I need Nuvigal and I just take 125 mgs or less mostly a little less. I also have been prescribed Clonazepam for general anxiety disorder accompanied with panic attacks . Also 20 mgs of fluoxetine.I am 60 years old with two sons 16 and 20 and my wife. Doing well . Nothing is perfect but I would say at this time that Seroquel is and has been the most important drug in my life as far as making a positive difference.

column2: Philos64, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: What I've learned from 8+ years of taking Seroquel:1. Gaining weight was a problem in the past, however it is not now. Exercising, eating lousy (yes, lousy), and taking supplements to help with the vitamin deficiencies have helped me over the years. My definition of eating lousy is: Ice Cream with lots of peanuts on top. At least once a day. I use protein shakes and mix in good things to make up for the loss of the most vital nutriants. I don't eat junk food, or drink soda. I drink iced tea and water. I've found that no calorie sweetners increase my anxiety. To help with constipation, I take an Acidopholus based supplement. Btw, I am NOT endorsing my methods of eating!2. Seroquel makes me "eat walk". Definition: 1/2-3/4 hour after taking my Seroquel, I get hungry, so I head for the kitchen and get something to eat. Unfortunately, eating kicks in my Seroquel, causing me to stumble about in the kitchen, and frequently falling. I have slept quite a few nights on the kitchen floor due to this. A friend of mine who witnessed this, told me I was like a kid who didn't want to go to bed at night.My answer to this has been to take a snack with me to bed. Because of this, I have many nightgowns with chocolate stains on them! A Seroquel friend of mine was the one who asked me if I had noticed that Seroquel kicks it in much more quickly after eating.3. Know your dose. If you're on the hypomanic side of bp, talk to your pdoc if adjusting the dosage is right for you. I have found that Seroquel does not help with my depression, so my pdoc adjusts my dosage accordingly. I am atypical, so my dosage needs are normally higher than most others.4. Don't give up the benefits of Seroquel because of the potential weight gain. Most of us know that finding a med that finally works can be really tough, and side effects come along with the package. There are so many different ways to stay active and get rid of any weight gain you might come across.If I can do make it, You can too!

column9: I was prescribed Seroquel and took it for only 4 days total.  I didn't even think the drug would be effective until it had built up in my system but perhaps it was because I was very malnourished and weak at the time I began to react within 24 hours.  It started a manic episode that literally had me smashing my head against the wall at work.  One co-worker found me lying unresponsive on the couch and thought I was dead, really I was just out-of-my-mind with panic, rage, and silent screams only I could hear.  I decided to take myself off it after that, as rogue librarians are frowned upon.  However, and I don't have any proof that this was a side effect of Seroquel and I'm sure people would argue with me but, for eight months afterwards and very seldom, to a far lesser extend, now I experienced pain in my shoulders and spine as if my skeleton were attempting to escape my body through the base of my neck.  I've eliminated all other culprits and those few days of Seroquel were when the pain began.  'Pain' does not even begin to describe what that felt like though. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone especially those recovering from illness.

column1: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed
column2: Jenntonic1, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I attempted suicide 2 months ago & landed in the hospital. (Honestly it was a blessing in disguise.) I had bouts of mania & depression on & off for over 18yrs untreated. At times I thought that there was nothing wrong with me & everyone else was the problem. During my 20's I experienced feelings of being immortal, invincible & on top of the world. I became a risk taker. All of these actions felt normal to me. I drank alcohol, used drugs, spent money without a care & later have buyers remorse or overwhelming feelings of guilt. Several times a year I would feel depressed & have thoughts of suicide but honestly never thought I would actually attempt it. Deep down I knew there was some type of chemical imbalance with the ups & down. Later I realized my actions greatly affected those around me. When I would start to feel mania or "normal",  I would forget about needing help & think everything was ok. Never once did I consider that I may have a mental illness. When I turned 30, I started having lower back pain that is now chronic. 3 years ago I also found out that I have arthritis and fibromyalgia & that these too are chronic. I tried a few antidepressants & pain management, none that really worked. I withdrew from life, stayed in bed & isolated myself, I became agitated, anxious & my stress level was through the roof. My relationship of 11 years became rocky & my partner left. Now, at 38yrs everything finally crashed together. So I tried to take my life.(I'm happy that didn't work out!) I was soon diagnosed with Bipolar I disorder during my hospital stay. My psychiatrist started me on a better pain regimen that works plus a low dose of Seroquel 50mg then up to only 100mg. My pain, mood & depression are more manageable & my relationship is back. I've combined that with therapy & proper rest. I'm back in my life and doing what I need to stay balanced. I have much work to do & may need to up my dose later. It's amazing how this med has evened me enough to enjoy life again.

column1: Mental Disorder with Loss of Normal Personality &amp; Reality
column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Control of behaviour; manic, psychotic, depression, anxiety, bipolar disorder. Aural and visual hallucinations under control- avoidance and/or recognition of triggers a big help. Still have memory hallucinations, e.g., the sound of a fridge or the sound of tyres will trigger a cacophonic symphony inside my head. Concentration and focus improved considerably. Sleeping well, solid 8 hrs a night, quick to sleep and clear head on immediate wake. Even tempered and serene compared to psychotic states. Digestion improved remarkably- no more accidents in public or having to plan a route for every outing that is no more than 5mins from a loo. Don't drink and have given up smoking, craving for sugars initially but now am sugar free. Never used to drink coffee but now can't put the stuff down. Down side is a distended stomach (think of ET) but there has been no weight gain. Libido non existent, incapable of even a faded echo of an erection.In short, I feel fantastic.

column2: Noinsulin, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have Fibromyalgia and had problems or no help with the usual sleep aids.  I didn't have the weight gain but I did have the fogginess and hard to wake up problems.  What I did get was Type II Diabetes.  I had no glucose problems when I started but I stopped it after I was in the E.R. for bronchitis and the doctor came back and asked me if I knew I was a diabetic.  My blood sugar count was 300.  I was floored.  I just finished a 3 yr class action suit with AstraZeneca since I'm not the only one but all I got from them was to be bent over and screwed and $5k for a lifetime of the possibility of blindness, amputation or death.  If I sound bitter, you bet I am.  I'm on 2 meds for the diabetes plus about 13 more for chronic pain, insomnia, neuropathy and other things.  It takes me 4 different narcotics to sleep and then it's not the kind of sleep I need.  Some nights, even with all of the meds, there is no sleep at all.I'm sorry for all that have bipolar but happy for the ones that have gotten help from this poison.  For the others, I hope you will find something that works for you.

column9: This drug was added to Nardil, Xanax, and Remeron.  Seroquel worked great.  Was on it for about 5 years.  It seemed to be the final anwser to my depression.  Of course, the weight gain was awful. About,6 months ago my glucose level was very high.  Found out that Seroquel can cause diabetes.  There was a class action suit against them, and they lost.  You can still enter in that suit for a few months yet.  I slowly went off Seroquel, was more carful of my diet, and my A1C a month later was normal.  As much as this drug helped, I will never take it again.  My depression has gotten a lot worse since going off of it.  Have tried almost everything that I can take with Nardil.  Don't know what to do next.

column1: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed
column2: Bandrew85, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Like many people who have been prescribed this medication I've been diagnosed with a mental health condition.  It is effective in that meets the expectations for treatment however it has a nasty "hangover" effect.  I've been on it a year or so and I still wake up groggy.  It has other side effects like leaving me tired all day, slurred speech and slower processing.  As an educator, it sometimes impacts my ability to be on my "A" game because I am tired.  It also makes me a little irritable--I'm not sure if the trade-off is worth it (e.g., the medication and its side effects in lieu of suffering from bipolar).  Unfortunately, most psychotropic drugs have a downer effect and this one is no different.  It seems my experience is on par with most other people's.  Two things I know for sure, do not drink alcohol while taking this medication and make sure you take it several hours before you go to sleep, despite what your doctor may tell you.  Also, this medication (at least in Illinois) can get you a DUI if you are under its influence and driving.  Be aware!

column2: Luna, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this for sleep for about 12 years and in different dosages. Now I am on Seroqel CR and having *some* problems adjusting. Everyone is different but 50 mgs is very high to me and with the Seroquel CR I kind of feel like a zombie in the morning; a bit agitated at night. Prob 'cuz I have tried to cut this in half and take it: Bad idea! Cutting it made me feel sick. Also I have diareeha and trouble driving. **NOTE: I have only been on CR for three weeks: The reg dose I used to take (25mgs) was fine and helped me sleep without anxiety--yet had diareeha only on occasion...when I ate right before bed. If you do feel hungry just eat some crackers or something not anything big--that is the key to not gaining a lot of weight.:) And exercise/eat right..I know *reader eye roll*but it helps. I wish the CR of Seroquel came in 25mg! I would advise eating early if you can and take it WHEN YOU ARE IN BED/READY TO SLEEP.If you skip a dose and can't sleep that's why 'cuz you may have restlessness from not taking it. Take it the next night;try to keep the timing the same.Don't watch anything "weird" on TV or you can have nightmares- sometimes I just read.Good Luck everyone and sweet dreams!

column1: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed
column2: eternity26, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Seroquel for I believe 8 years now. IT IS A WONDER DRUG!!!! Yes I too gained weight in the first month. It was worth it to me to be "sane" again!!! I have always suffered from what I thought was severe mania and I would work with my doctor and he let me adjust my meds accordingly. I don't drink alcohol OR do drugs that is a huge factor in the seroquel working for me! I was on very  high dose's of seroquel It was my decision not my doctors because of the delusions prior to me taking seroquel were very scary to me! It was like I was trapped in another world and I wasn't having fun! I  was on an average 300 mil of seroquel every night but at some points 600mil.  I was at the same job for 8 years and didn't even know they (my co workers) were stressing me out to the point I had to take such high doses. Well I was fired from that job and 3 months later I'm down to 100 mill a night and I have NEVER been happier! I'm a hair dresser and my clients all can tell I'm a different person!!! I've started losing weight 10 pounds since my dosages have changed. (  I lowered my meds  VERY SLOWLY,  otherwise you could spiral into depression) It really helps if you know the signs of your symptons. Which I was in denial because I was always happy (or so I thought) I didn't agree with the depression symptoms the internet told me I was having. But I now know it was the truth. I would have lowered my meds ALOT SOONER, IF I realized I wasn't as manic as I thought. I'm not sure if anyone else read before about when depressed we stop taking showers, Well I was only taking showers once a week, for time sakes or I'd be late for work! No one ever knew! I didn't smell or try to cover it up with perfume! Of course I never went to the gym so I was never sweaty and all gross! Well I hoped this has helped someone, if you'd like to contact me I'm at creative.hair.genius@gmail.comI'm Kat BTW. Good luck and GOD BLESS

column2: schtinky, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: WARNING:  Do not let your doctor talk you into taking this medicine while you are on any anxiety medication like xanax or ativan.  I had a SEVERE and scary reaction to the combination of Serequel and Ativan - I blacked out in a fugue and had a psychotic episode.  I remember nothing of it but both my mother and husband witnessed abnormal behavior such as flushing all my medication, putting turkey salad in a bowl and pouring milk on it like cereal, and thinking my socks were a chocolate bar.  This side effect isn't included in the 'interactions' portion but there is a caution regarding use of anxiety medication.  Seroquel is DANGEROUS.  I could have seriously injured myself, and its frightening to not remember a thing you did or said while others tell you that you were acting psychotic.  Ask for another medication such as risperidone that isn't as dangerous as Seroquel.

column2: ambrakay, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Immediately after the removal of my brain tumor and my temporal lobe resection, I was suffering from major depressive disorder with having my amygdala removed, not to mention 30% of my brain.  A psychiatrist, not allowing me to so much as explain that I'd had brain surgery 6 weeks prior, within less than a minute declared I was bipolar and told me to stop my Lexapro (for generalized anxiety disorder) cold turkey and start taking Seroquel.  He started me on 50 mgs with the intent of getting me up to 300.  By the 3rd week, when I was up to 150 mgs, I wanted to die.  I couldn't stop crying and I slept for at least 13 hours a night.  I was soooo miserable.  Then my seizures came back with a vengeance.  I called my neuro and he told me anyone with epilepsy is not to take any ana-antipsychotics.  I stopped Seroquel immediately and weaned back onto my Lexapro and saw a psychiatrist who works specifically with epilepsya patients who put me on .5 mgs Risperdal for 3 mos as a booster to my Lexapro to get me through the hump of post surgical depression.  That did the trick :-)  By the way, I've since seen 2 other psychiatrists who have confirmed that I do not have depression, nor am I bipolar.

column9: I started taking this medication about 3 years ago and it was tough at first. It knocked me out and took a while to adjust to. I suppose it has helped with my mania (I seem to only have them when I drink-- not a good idea). Overall I am able to focus, process, and make responsible decisions now. The draw back is the weight gain- which just in the last six months has become noticeable and embarrassing. That alone makes me dislike my self image- but who wouldn't. The worst part for me is knowing that I can never come off of this drug because I ran out several months ago and experienced awful withdrawals. I was so sick and my insides hurt. I felt like I was dying. I never want to experience that again ever. It was terrible. As long as I take the drug daily and do not drink I am fine. I'll have to do something about this 20+ pounds on my tiny frame though. My clothes don't fit! Just do everything you can to not go through the withdrawals. And consider this a warning- you might get stuck taking this forever. Bonus- AZ&Me has patient plans and financial assistance to those who qualify.

column2: Crash85, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: When I was first diagnosed as Bi-Polar approx. 10 years ago, I was put on an SSRI. The SSRI had bad side effects, and I stopped taking. I have tried several different SSRI Anti-Depressants during this 10 year span. Approx. 3 years ago I ended up in a Mental Health Facility, and while in there I saw a psychiatrist. After an assessment the Doctor again diagnosed me as Bi-polar with an added diagnosis of Severe Anxiety w/Panic Attacks, and again tried another SSRI that was fairly new to me at the time called Celexa. I took it for about a month or so until the same side effects I have always had with SSRIs began. So I went to my new doctor and explained this to him. He then prescribed me Seroquel to try as an alternative to an SSRI, at first at a low dosage, than higher as I needed it. Not only did it NOT cause the same unwanted side effects as the SSRIs did, it eased my conditions very well and proved to be extremely effective. It has successfully countered my Bi-Polar Disorder for the last 3 or so years. It also aides with the Severe Anxiety & Panic Attacks (along with Clonazepam). Lastly, I have also been diagnosed as an Insomniac and again Seroquel alone has also conquered that diagnosis as well. All in all, while this medicine is expensive due to the lack of generics (patent hasn't expired) it is well worth the money as I have had multiple disabling problems managed with the use of this one drug. The price of the medication can be adjusted with insurance, and/or a financial plan with the Drug Company themselves who offer RX Discounts, and free medication to those who are in need. The only bad side effects I have experienced with this medication is occasional nightmares, and dry mouth in the morning. I hope this helps anyone thinking of taking this medication. For my situation it was a PERFECT solution, and it may be the answer for you as well. Always talk to your doctor and weigh the pros and cons.

column9: Used to use this for sleep @50mgs at hs. Worked very well but was getting groggy during the day and less focused, also memory problems.Then read it ups triglycerides and cholesterol.Also realized it was used off label and was anti-depressant.Realize there are many people caught in a catch 22 situation and Need these types of meds.,at least short term but Newsweek 2/10/2010, magazine showed studies that seem to prove the newer drugs simply do not work. Short term possibly,(one rebuttal) but to take one then add another which seems to be current practice because one seems to not work as well anymore just doesn't make sense to me related to all the other side effects that then need to be txd. also with more and more meds. and then those side effects from those meds in a vicious circle.I truly believe one of the problems created by preventive medicine is the same problems seen with defensive medicine. Meds are now being prescribles to large populations of people who really don't need them based on unproven results and anecdotal theories. Try reading a few of books now being published about over-treatment in this country. Now I take fish oil and scripts short term only as needed. Have read now that the fish oil doesn't work either but so far it doesn't look like it does harm either.

column9: Works well if you have sleep deprivation.  I use other medications for several different conditions, however, the lack of sleep over takes everything. column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Seroquel was expensive and no fun at all.  After taking my dose, I would be in between sleep and wakefulness.  I would not be able to sleep, but would be very drowsy and yet restless.  It was a very uncomfortable feeling.  I would lie down and not be able to get comfortable.  The uncomfortable feeling occurred whether I took Seroquel in the morning or at night.  I kept taking it anyway.  I can't say how much it helped and how much was the natural course of my bipolar disorder.  But I would not take it again if I had the choice (and fortunately nobody's asking me to.)  Maybe it will work for you, but not for me.  I haven't taken it in years.  Now I'm on a generic version of Lamictal and a generic version of Risperdal.  Risperdal used to have a similar effect on me, but it doesn't anymore.  Maybe it was my drinking that caused the unpleasant side effects.  Who knows why these drugs work this way?  I sure don't.  But I'm much better without drinking.  I recommend it (quitting drinking).

column2: BigTownGirl, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I take a half tablet (25 mg) when I start to have a panic attack and it works amazingly. I have obsessive compulsive personality disorder (which includes generalized anxiety disorder)as well as chronic depression. My OCPD is actually quite helpful when it comes to work and some social situations, so I don't take anything daily. I only take Seroquel a couple of times a month, so I have not experienced any weight gain. What I love so much about seroquel is that  when I'm starting to get worked up and breathing heavy and highly agitated, I can take half a pill and it makes me feel really really normal. Seriously. A normal I haven't felt in my life. I've taken it when I interviewed at my grad school for admission. I had 2 days of classes I had to sit in on and tons of important people to meet and impress and blend in with. SO stressful. I popped one in the morning when I noticed my hand shaking, and BOOM! I got a little tired about 5 hours into it. I took it once when I thought I was upset before a family gathering, but it turns out I didn't get anywhere near a panic attack and ended up falling asleep at the dinner table. Seroquel really really helps with my panic attacks. I have used these anti-depressants without too much success: prozac, zoloft, celexa, and fluoxetine.

column2: kprobson, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was given this drug because I wasn't sleeping.  I still didn't sleep with the medicine, but it did give me nasty twitching, such that as I walked down the hall at work, my arm would shoot out like I was batting at something.  I couldn't think straight or formulate words.  With permission, I got off the meds as soon as I could. I was told that Benedryl helps to get this stuff out of your system (I did take it), but 4 years after stopping the medicine I still occasionally still twitch.  If I could go back, I would have asked the doc if there wasn't something more safe for my problem (20mg Ambien wasn't working).  If you can't sleep, take something else.  It's not worth it in my opinion.

Im on 250 mg. and was on 750 mg. when I had a TIA and was in the hospital for 5 days.I have uncontrollable, IRREVERSABLE movement in my fingers and hands. I am a professional musician , so you can understand my horror.At this point, as I write, I have intense, muscle cramping in my torso and have put a call into my Psych. Dr. and my neurologist. I am not psychotic, nor have I ever been. Go to beyondmeds.com and read first hand, well written accounts of this stuff. Be well. xoxo

column9: I did experience bloating and weight gain, I think, around the abdomen especially. It left me feeling very "slow", uninspired (I am an artist and this has been difficult for me). It (the Seroquel) also gave me nausea and a sense of apartness from others.  Maybe that was good, given how difficult a time I was having coping with others in that period,a nd that I had recently been extremely traumatized by an abusive relationship w/a former partner.  I don't think I would recommend this drug for everyone.  I think there are others that may do as well and that the pharmaceutical that manufactures/distributes it allows me to obtain the drug free-of-charge is part of why I THINK it may have been given me, rather than something else. column9: i take seroquel for bi polar disorder i have manic days off and on and racing thoughts and nightmares, insomnia, i been on 300 mg for the last year and i find it very helpful. i have lesser anxiety attacks, no racing thoughts, i sleep better, and i dont have the urge to cry all the time. the bad thing is once i run out and cant get my prescription filled i have withdrawls, i sweat my heart races i shake all over esp my legs, i feel like i cant breath and i cry all the time, it really sucks because i have bad racing thoughts about dieing and killing myself it is not fun at all, i worry a lot too and my stress level is beyond repair.  the medicine works wonders ans i suggest to anyone with depression/bi polar to ask your doctor if seroquel is right for you, i started with the small dose and worked my way up to 300 mg i been suffering from depression since i was a teenager and i finally tried to treat it 8 years ago after i had my son. my fiancee doesnt understand my depression and im trying to show him to the best of my abilities what its all about hes been a great supporter. try seroquel and see if its helpful to you i know it is for me.

column2: copslstopya, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: Read the insert. This medication slowly kills you if you don't die because of its similar action to alcohol. It was just like being drunk except no euphoria. I was expelled from public venues while on this drug because the consensus was that I "was drunk or on drugs". I was refused service at fast food and told the 'cops have been called" because I was staggering and slurring speech. I cut and bruised myself countless times without knowing how.  I tripped and fell because I could not lift my toes when walking. All this as a man in his prime.   Being compelled to be on this drug because to refuse would have resulted in depot injections of an even more damaging and debilitating drug still has me exasperated more than a decade later. I was subjected to an injustice by being compelled to eat this poison and an insult for being billed for  the cost of the pills.  Every time I see an auto accident I wonder if this drug or some other psych med is involved.This chemical should be banned and the knowledge of it be allowed to expire from human consciousness.It effects healthy and not so healthy persons  and mammals in an identical fashion.  It has no core effect.  It is a confusing blend of side effects and produces extreme paradoxical reactions within only a few hours in some individuals.   It is carcinogenic and how a doctor sworn to "do no harm" could consider it for inclusion in their practice baffles me.

column2: Jackson, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was put on Seroquel a few months ago for Mixed State Bipolar Disorder. My condition was mild and primarily depressed with some anxiety and OCD until trying Lexapro a few months which triggered an awful mixed episode. At first, as with almost everyone, I was started on a low dose of Seroquel, in my case to be elevated in three stages. The first two went pretty smoothly after a few days of brain fog and fatigue. I did not feel 100%, but was alot better than I had been, and started to enjoy life again. My depression was greatly alleviated and my anxiety became totally manageable.  However, I have had a very hard time dealing with the third stage of titration (still a comparably low dose considering how much some others are taking), which even after a few days I am finding too sedating and have new side effects such as a kind of pressure headache. I know it needs to be bumped up as the initial relief I have had with the lower dosages have waned a good bit. I am just really hoping I can adjust to it and get the same results consistently in the future. Also,even with insurance, this is proving to be a very costly medication. I am happy with it because it is the only med that has provided many any relief, but you may want to discuss alternatives considering its sedation and high price.

column2: bclark, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Due to my husband's serious illness, working, other terrible family problems, I developed worsening of my depression and anxiety.  I then developed nausea and couldn't eat or drink.  I lost 15 lbs. in two weeks.  I went to the ER three times and each time they changed my anxiety meds.  I ended up knowing I had to try something else.  I am a nurse and I called our mental health facility.  They told me to come in and after an extensive interview, I was admitted for four days.  They stopped my meds and put me back on Effexor, but Klonopin for anxiety and added Seroquel 100mg.  The first night after I took it and went to bed, I felt a burning in my shoulders.  This is often related to my anxiety episodes so I figured the new meds weren't going to work.  Next thing I knew I felt this wonderful peace come over me and I slept like a baby.  After three days the nurses said,"You're feeling better, aren't you"?  And I sure was.  I took Seroquel for about a year and added talk therapy.  I did gain 20 lbs. but I had a quiet mind, didn't stress, and my life got back on track.  I eventually was able to go off of the Seroquel.

column2: Danielle, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: i was prescribed seroquel to help alleviate the symptoms of marijuana withdrawal. i was a chronic smoker for three years and became both mentally and physically dependent. i was trying to self medicate, but it only made my bipolar and anxiety disorders worse. my psychiatrist prescribed 50mg of seroquel to combat the insomnia, loss of appetite, anxiety, depression and racing thoughts that accompanied my withdrawal. plus, it gives you a similar feeling of being high. i was told to take 25mg at night before going to sleep and 50mg if i have an anxiety attack. i did gain a considerable amount of weight...but that's nothing compared to being sober and getting control of my life. i am tapering off of seroquel right now because i feel that i don't need it anymore. i'm currently cutting the pill in fourths, so i take 12.5mg every night. overall, this medication felt like a godsend. many people cannot handle the effects of seroquel, but i would highly recommend that if you're struggling with a drug addiction to seek help from a medical professional and ask about seroquel. it will ease withdrawal symptoms considerably.

column2: MSQUEEN1997, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: For the past four months, I have been taking Seroquel (600 mg.) and Effexor (300 mg.) for severe depression and anxiety. I have been on Effexor for five years, which began with 75 mg. was increased to 150 mg, and then to 225 mg. before beginning the Seroquel. Once I started this one, the Effexor was bumped up to 300 mg. Since beginning this high dose combination, I have gained 26 lbs., began chewing the skin on my fingers (nervousness), have vivid nightmares, constant sweating, dizzy spells, loss of memory, itchiness, sleepiness, losing my chain-of-thought in the middle of a sentence, shortness of breath, and heart palpitations. On one occasion, I passed out in the bathroom, and woke up in a fog  wondering how and why I was in the floor. While the severity of the depression, anxiety (and muscular pain from Fibromyalgia) has lessened, I continue to have little interest in getting out of bed, leaving home, interacting with others, and driving. In the past, I have tried other medications for depression (e.g., Prozac, Celexa, and Cymbalta), and did not have as many issues. I took Prozac for about six years and only experienced talking excessively. With the Celexa and Cymbalta, I experienced insomnia and continued having episodes of depression and anxiety, but not as severe as I had when I did not take any medication. With the symptoms I am having with this current combination, I am not sure which medications will work for me, but I plan to consult my doctor about a few of the medications some of you mentioned (i.e., Abilify, Remeron, and Lamictil). Also, I have a prosthetic heart valve and the last thing I need is an increase in the symptoms I am having with the Seroquel!!

column2: GuitarEyez, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: So, I've been taking Seroquel for about 3 years.  400mg at night along with 300mg Welbeutrin XL in the morning.  I was perscribed many different drugs, but this is the ONLY one that works for me.  No more suicide attempts and my moods are much more stable.  It does have some side effects but if you can learn how to work with them, they aren't an issue.  I've never ever been able to sleep at night, but an hour after taking Seroquel, I'm out.  I love it.  It did cause me to gain 30lbs, but once I fought through the cravings, I was fine.  Lost all the extra weight and my diet is back to normal.  Since I take it at night and it knocks me out, I know I need to get at least six hours of sleep or I get the "hangover" effect in the morning.  The only thing I don't like about it is that I get ripped from my sleep at least once a night.  Nightmares, but the racing heart is a little scary.  It goes away within a minute or so of me waking.  Then I'm back to sleep without any problems.  I don't mind the nightmares.  It's better then spending weeks at a time in Psychiatric care.  So yeah, I love it.

column2: 7-12 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: My 7yr granddaughter,whom we have been raising since the age of 5 mths,has been on this medication for Bi-Poler Mania almost 3 years now with great results,although a slight weight gain,just watching her carbs & sugar intake keeps that under control.She is SO much calmer.where at first she would "rage" to the point of picking up a 2 wheel bike @ age 4 & throwing it about 10 ft,she would bite herself & others even bringing blood at times.The rages would become SO bad that even applying "passive" restraint(as told by psychologist)was almost impossible even though we outweigh her by 100#.Now she is a straight A student in the 2nd grade & her teachers are amazed at the results & the difference in her ability to concentrate much much better.she sleeps through the night without any sluggishness or grogginess the next morning.Her self control is allot better for her to do,she's able to "think" before she reacts where before she wasn't able to,She is in NO way a "zombie" at any time throughout the day.She takes 50mg at noon & 100 mg at bedtime (8pm)along with Concerta ER 36 mg(in the am for ADHD).I am in NO means saying that every adult or every child will have these same results,but for our granddaughter & for us,Seroquel,along with therapy has been a life saver.It is my hope that more people that have Bi-Polar Mania will be able to find relief & control over their lives with whatever their Dr's medicine regimen may be.God Bless

column2: Riga, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Seroquel worked wonders once when I was experiencing a consistent feeling of unreality for days. The very next day I began to feel at home in the world, not anxious or depressed.  However, as soon as the drug started to take effect (I took it at night), I would be so dizzy I couldn't walk without holding on to furniture.  I would fall asleep anywhere--on the floor of the closet while looking for something in a box, on the floor on my exercise mat, standing up in the kitchen drinking a cup of coffee.  I'd wake up when the coffee spilled or I started to fall (if I was standing up), but I had a horrible experience waking up on the floor of the closet covered in clothing that had fallen on top of me, not being able to remember where I might be--it was pitch black, I was covered in something--was I in hell?  I didn't think I was dead but I was terrified until I crawled out of the closet and realized I was in my bedroom.  My husband would find me sleeping on the floor all over the house.  So, I went down on the dose. Still had side effects (less though)and it didn't work as a sleeping pill for me. Right now I'm trying not to take it until I need it again.  It is a VERY effective drug but side effects are surreal.

column2: Southern Lady, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking Seroquel four year ago to treat severe insomnia.  I started taking 350 mg.  After two months of hardly any sleep and feeling "homocidal", this drug finally got me the sleep I needed.  However, as with others who have written, I would get the "munchies" within 1/2 hour of taking it and gained weight.  I also feel like a zombie in the mornings unless I get about 10 hours of sleep.  Over time, I whittled down the amount of dosage little by little.  I am now taking somewhere between 35-38 or so mg. (I cut the pills with a pill cutter).  This is the least I can use without disrupting my sleep. I still have trouble getting up early (less than 8 hours) in the morning.  The way I resolve the "feeding frenzy"  I take the Seroquel within 10 minutes of going to bed before the "munchies" kick in.  I eventually want to get off the drug all together because you know the damage presdcription drugs can do to the kidneys. "less is more" in this case, which is why I reduced the amount of dosage.  For those using Seroquel just for insomnia, experiment with dosage reduction and go to bed directly after taking it to avoid overeating/raiding the fridge and gorging (yes....I did it and gained 25 pounds.....trying to work it off).

column2: anonymous, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I am a firm believer that every medication works differently on different people. But if you start having neg effects they are most likely only going to get worse. This cured my anxiety/panic attacks @ a low dose of 150 mg. My psychiatrist raised it to 400 mg and w/in a week I lost control of every party of my body and the side effects outweighed my anxiety/panic attacks. Massive twitching and muscle spasms from my face down to my ankles, I couldn't make my eyes stop moving and I was starting to see things jump and things that were not there, foggy mind, slurring and stuttering speach, hot and cold flashes, cold sweat, I did not feel more hungry but I never felt full so I ate all the time, tingling from face to legs, my mind was not sharp (I had trouble even remembering simple words and barely was able to finish a complete sentence), forgetfulness, constipation (had to see gastrointerologist b/c I wouldn't have bowel movements for a week @ time..very painful), anxiety b/c of my fear of the side effects...I never understod how a med could make someone feel like they're dying but I was experiencing all these symptoms @ one time and it became unbearable. Withdrawal symptoms are just as unbearable as the side effects. Simply put, Seroquel made me feel like every part of my body and brain was going through retardation.

column2: christinep22, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: This medication was terrible!!!!!  I was diagnosed with bipolar disorder and started on Seroquel.  Within a week I felt like a different person, constantly in a fog.  And good god, the sleeping...I slept CONSTANTLY.  When I took the first dose, I got up once to use the bathroom, and other than that slept for 30 something hours.  I gave it time for the side effects to wear down and continuously slept for at least 14-16 hours a day until I stopped taking the medication.  Also, I gained over 40 pounds in 4 months while I took it.  I felt hungry constantly.  It helped with my depression and bipolar at first, but after a month or so, what good effects it had wore down.  Before taking this I could've been considered a nymphomaniac (an effect of bipolar, I know), but this medication made me lose ALL interest in sex.  And this has become a long-term problem.Also, DO NOT GO OFF THIS MEDICATION WITHOUT TAPERING OFF WITH HELP FROM YOUR DOCTOR.  I could no longer afford it, so instead of paying attention and tapering off of it, I just stopped.  I was sick for days.  Felt horrible mentally and threw up constantly.  This medication may help some but it was absolutely horrible for me.  If you have issues with it, talk to your doctor instead of thinking the effects will go away.

column2: yin and yang, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: i have been taking the drug for two years to treat my bipolar disorder(NOS. i first started off with 50 mg then eventually went up to 300 mg (100 in am 200 in pm). while on the drug i was completely out of it i slept 10 hours at night woke up and then slept 4 hours in nthe morning, the rest of teh day i slept on and off, this caused me a lot of trouble with my job causing me to eventually lose it. the time i was awake was spent in deep depression  other times i was completely manic, living one step from the edge, i eventually entered a manic episode that peaked with insane rage (cannibalistic desires) and after a couplke of hours ofd tearing everything around me apart and randomly spitting all over the place and clawing at my walls and hearing screeching inside my skull,i immediately dropped to a low where i attempted suicide with the seroquel itself. i woke up in icu barely alive with cataracts that eventually cleared up...i got on lithium but kept the seroquel and i was perfect. once i got past the severe headaches (2 to 3 times a week-cure sleep)and diarreah(everyday plus vomitting for teh first two weeks, now i randomly get it), the lithium helped with my mania and with seroquel i get the sleep i need at night(with the occasional dream of hell or some taboo thing).SEROQUEL BY ITSELF DID NOT WORK BUT IN COMBO WITH A ANTI DEPRESSANT AND ANOTHER BIPOLAR MED IT WORKS WONDERS,a  PSYCHOLOGIST THAT I HAVE SEEN HAS SAID THAT COMMONLY IT TAKES TWO BP MEDS TO WORK EFFECTIVELY but everyone is different, i am more stable now than i ever been since i was 13 years old, its put an end on the strain its caused my family(dealing with a unstable bp in mania = divorce, and now i am studying engineering in college)

column1: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Have been on Lamictal about 8 years, added Seroquel about 2 years ago and have never been more stable emotionally--I have a good job and good relationships and I haven't had an episode in 2 years since I've been on it--and bipolar does not control me anymore.  Good combo of drugs.  However, Seroquel's side effects are considerable.  They are manageable, but you have to put in some effort--get blood tests to check your thyroid and cholesterol and fats, eat really healthy and work out or you will gain weight, schedule your days so you can always get 9-10 hours of sleep even if you have to go to bed by 8pm.  The heart palpitations don't hit me if I stay in bed once I take it--the palpitations only show up if I try to fight through the drowsiness to move around, so I just plan to be in bed for 10 hours.  It's a question of what you're willing to put up with to be stable emotionally.  Bipolar made my life hell, as long as I could remember, and for the first time, I've been stable for more than a few weeks at a time.  2 good years and counting.

column2: PurplePassion, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have suffered from depression my entire life. A decade ago, I was involved in a very traumatic experience that sent me into a downward spiral. I was diagnosed with acute clinical depression with PTSD and Anxiety. After trying every single anti-depressant out there with no improvement and some worsening the conditions, I finally got on Pristiq. It helped a lot but I still suffered from mood swings occasionally and insomnia every night. My dr prescribed Seroquel. I am much more calm. I was on 300mg but have gone down to 200mg. I take it at night. At first, it knocked me out almost immediately and I slept through the night. After being on it for over a year, it's not as effective at helping me fall asleep but once I am asleep, I stay asleep. However, there is a HUGE side effect that I've suffered greatly from and that is weight gain. I've gained 45lbs since being on it. When I would take it, I would develop the munchies identical to those you get when you're under the influence of alcohol or marijuana. The desire for food is too hard for me to fight. However, I am a food addict so I am sure this plays a lot into my problem with not being able to control myself when I get the "hungries" this drug causes. Other than that, I've had no other side effects besides daytime sleepiness but it usually wears off once I get going. As well as this drug has worked for me, I now have diabetes and am morbidly obese so I plan on switching the drugs around. I recommend this drug to anyone who is NOT a food addict and needs a boost to their antidepressant and help sleeping at night. Try to stay at the lowest effective dose you can to minimize side effects. Wish me luck! I am going to switch to abilify and try ambien or lunesta again, even though they haven't been that helpful in the past.

column2: dntsaynuthn, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: When I started Seroquel I was more satisfied than ever with how I felt on the medication, I felt more in control of myself then ever. I hadnt changed my eating habits, but when I when to my psychiatrist I asked to have my weight taken and I had gained 32 lbs in less than 3 months!  I was on Seroquel and then tried Seroquel XR to try to relieve the weight gain but unfortunately I had to switch medications because the weight gain was a steady gain.  I would monitor your weight closely while on this medication.

column2: Sam, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Seroquel for a couple years now and have had awesome success! First starting it was a lil rough just because you do feel really tired for a couple weeks, but nothing to bad. Especially in comparison to how I was feeling. I was getting panic attacks on a daily basis, and then crashing hard into depression. I started at 50 mg 1 x a day, now I take 400mg 2 x a day and have been very even. Of course there are ups and downs.. as life does throw us curve balls here and there. But I have felt able to cope with them. I also take Zoloft for depression, that combo has worked out really good for me. I am thinking about adding lithium to my regime just because I am now starting to have higher ups and lower lows.. maybe that will help balance things back out. All though I have had a lot of recent stresses added to my life, a little something extra would probably help me out for a short term thing. If you haven't tried it, it's worth giving a shot!

column9: I was prescribed Seroquel (25mg Tablets) to take 1 tablet by mouth as needed for anxiety and sleep (up to 8 tablets in 24 hours). I've also noticed/experienced a constant need to move my legs (restless leg syndrome), shakiness in my movements and voice, dry-mouth, increased temperature/fever immediately after taking, tinnitus (ringing in the ears), mental/mood changes (e.g., increased anxiety, depression, suicidal thoughts).PLEASE, SERIOUSLY SPEND SOME TIME CONSIDERING THESE SIDE EFFECTS I HAVE MENTIONED ABOVE. From what I have read, some of these side effects can even be PERMANENT. I hope a week wasn't enough time to have irreversibly damaged my system.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
MadMomma, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on Seroquel for the last 5 years and thank God every day my doctor found it.  I was a mess, hadnt slept in months, manic right to the edge. Then we found Seroquel.  From the 1st 25 mg dose, I felt different. I worked slowly up to 150, didnt like the effects at that dose and went down to 100 mgs. Doc and I agree that sometimes the dose needs to be adjusted to help me cope with stress (which brings on the MANIC MONSTER) but lower dose is usually good for all.  And it allows me to practice other coping techniques. So I watch what I eat, control the carb cravings with health snacks and get my 8 hours.  I would rather deal with the side effects than live like a lunatic on the fringe.

column2: Aunt Freda, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Seroquel lowered my blood pressure so much I had to stay in the hospital 8 days.  My blood pressure hovered around 60 over 40.  I kept losing my vision, falling down, heard buzzing or ringing sounds, slurred my speach.It was terrifying.  I had taken seroquel for a couple of years before having the acute adverse reaction.  I also became so sleepy I would sleep for two or three days at a time.  When I finally stopped taking it I lost 35lbs.  I believe that the medication has very long term effects on my brain.  I haven't taken it in three months now and I still feel foggier and more stupid than I used to be.My memory seems to be permanently changed.  I cannot remember as well as I used to before taking this drug.Physicians are prescribing it to large numbers of patients now.  I think there will be a large population of people who are less intelligent than they were prior to taking the drug.Also, there is no cure for hypotension.  So, if you get it like I did, you are just plain screwed.  Spend time considering these side effects.  I think they may be permanent.

column9: I started taking Seroquel for my bipolar disorder several years ago at first it worked well helping me get much needed sleep. I did have a hard time being alert on it. My dose gradually increased over time and added lamictal to it. I was taking 200mg  in the morning 200 in the afternoon and 400 at bed time. This medication worked very well however the side effects were not worth it all it made me gain weight but the problem came when I had my blood drawn and we were able to see what was going on inside  this medication raised my cholesterol messed up my sugar and my thyroid. The only good news I have after being off it for a year everything is almost back to normal. If you are taking this medication you should have blood work done on a regular basis

column2: dps, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: DIABETICS PLEASE READ if you are considering this drug. The only reason for one star is that if you are diabetic DO NOT TAKE THIS DRUG.  Don't get me wrong it works well but it did take some time to get used to it (out of body feeling, severe muscle twitches and cramps, feeling like I was not standing on the floor but rather floating).  Then after taking it for about a year developed HIGH cholesterol (651) and OFF THE SCALE  triglycerides (over 4600 - yes 4600 - not a mistake) in blood tests at Mayo Clinic. A soon as  I stopped taking it and all went back to normal with temporary help from chol/trig meds.  By the way docs at Mayo are not allowed to give it to diabetic patients.  But it does work for mania/manic periods.

column2: Laurence, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This was NOT being used for anxiety attacks. It was being administered for on going anxiety. I started the medication with a dosage of 25mg, twice a day.  Reportedly a low dosage. column2: alshakat, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: My son was taking this.  Worse medicine I've ever seen.  I would hate going to see him, for fear that he would be dead.  I have never seen him look so bad.  It was HORRIBLE!  He never left the house, sat in the dark until it was time to work, went home and did the same thing again.  I told him to get off of it.  Wean himself off for 7 days.  He wasn't happy with me, to say the least, but he knew he was a mess.  A year later, 1,500 miles away, we got a call.  His dad was DEAD.....  Coincidently, he was taking the same medication.  His parents found him, like I imagined finding my son.  But, they were not monitoring him, like I was doing for my son.  My ex's heart stopped...  He wasn't sick, no heart problems, but he was taking too much medicine, and it stopped his heart.  He was so messed up from it that he couldn't remember how many pills he had taken, and took more.  55 years old, with no health problems, and DEAD!  This medication should be BANNED imediately.  My son use to complain about how I made him "STOP" taking his meds.....  I haven't heard a thing since his dad died.  I know he appreciates what I did, even though he wasn't happy about it in the beginning.  If you have any other alternatives, use them.  This med is dangerous & deadly.  Try medical marajuana!  I may be weird, but I believe that it is natural, and safer than anything out there.  My son refused to try it, and then last year, he did at 33 y/o.  Said it was the first time in his life he felt "normal"......  And I am totally against illegal drugs, more than most people.  But, I believe that natural is the way to go. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have Bipolar II and from my personal experience I do NOT recommend this medication.  I was on 400mg/day for just over 2 years, and was also taking 300mg/day of Lamictal.  At first the Seroquel was beneficial, but after a while the side effects began to greatly outweigh the positives.  It was great for putting me to sleep, and though I didn't have too much trouble waking up, I did have problems feeling awake for most of the day.  It also gave me double vision for a couple of hours mid-morning, which obviously made all activities difficult/dangerous.  I also experienced auditory hallucinations, though not intense or alarming.  I truly only noticed them once they were absent after stopping the medication.  The withdrawl was horrible.  I was constantly sick to my stomach, could barely eat, and vomited for over a month.  However, it was worth it!  I still experience mild hypomanic episodes, but not as serious previous to the Seroquel.  I still remain on the Lamictal and it has been a savior.

column9: I have been diagnosed with chronic pancreatitis, as well as kyphoscoliosis. I was going up to almost 5 days without being able to sleep. It got to the point I felt like I was being tortured, and couldn't function with 2 children. So thank God for my psychiatrist! Where my regular doctors did nothing, he never stop trying to find something to help me. Hence, Seroquel. The 1st dose, I slept so hard! Like a baby. I woke up more refreshed I couldn't believe it. As far as people who have a drug history being prescribed this medication, I dont think they should be. I do believe it has some sedative qualities and can be sold and abused. But I have seen my psychiatrist for 5 years and knows my circumstances and doesn't just give it out like candy. He discusses the medications purpose and explains why he suggests that I try  that medication. So if someone is being given the medication and selling it, they are the ones who end up ruining it for those who really need it. Especially when it doesn't get you "high".

The doctor gradually increased the dose to 300mg.  In the past 3 months, I have gained almost 30lbs.  Prior to the medication, I was hardly hungry.  Now it seems like I can't get full.  Also began cutting myself when extremely stressed.  Not sure if this was from the seroquel since I don't have a history of cutting.  I found it very difficult to wake in the morning.  I have a 19 month old child and I never hear him cry in the mornings.  It's a good thing my husband is home to hear him. Having a young family, this drug was very difficult to use.  Having to take it pretty much as soon as I got home, to make sure that I would get enough sleep to hear the alarm in the morning.  I needed to have at least 12 hours of sleep.  It's just not possible to spend time with my husband and take care of my child on this medication.  At this point, my doctor is gradually decreasing the dose and we are going to try ambilify (I think that is how to spell it).  Hopefully, it will work better for me.

column2: HappyLady1, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I am bipolar type II; my most destructive symptom is depression. 800 mg is my dose and it works wonderfully - note that 400 mg was NOT a theraputic dose for me, and it was only by overdosing one night (I was at the time very depressed) that I discovered a higher dose made me feel better. I am fully functional thanks to this medicine: attending work, spending time with friends and family, maintaining a healthy romantic relationship, and volunteering in my community. That said: this drug is NOT for everyone, and you should try drugs like Zoloft, Lexapro, Effexor etc before you try this drug because the side-effects can be horrible. My side effects are dry-mouth, severe drowsiness and akathesia, a painful panic=like attack that can cause me to walk around my apartment in circles for an hour or two after I take the drug. Luckily, my doctor and I found Mirapex, an anti-Parkinson's drug, to stop these panic episodes from occurring. I take a significant dose of Mirapex before bed, when I take Seroquel, and also usually smoke a small amount of marijuana, and this has allowed me to enjoy the benefits of Seroquel without the horrible panic. If you have akathesia as a side-effect, and the drug is helping you, please try Mirapex before you give up! Finally, please note that every story in this thread is one person's personal experience - including mine! - and none of these stories are an accurate portrayal of what you will experience yourself if you try this drug. I mean this as both a warning and an encouragement; only you and your doctor can decide if this drug is right for you, and I hope our stories make you more informed in this decision. God bless.

If you are experiencing terrible side effects you need to try a different drug or combination of drugs. Most of us have to endure being a guinea pig until the right balance of meds is found.  Hang in there & you will get your life back.

column2: Trying2sleep, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Psychiatrist prescribed for sleep problems that include difficulty falling asleep and staying asleep for about 3 yrs now and getting worse (sometimes go 3 nights w/o sleep). After practicing the usual sleep hygiene recommended by regular Dr which includes breathing relaxation, no caffiene etc. I started with 25mg of Seroquel. I'm now up to 50 mg because i still wake up during the night frequently. My main problem with this drug is the fact that I need to take it no later than 9pm to get to sleep by 10:30 or so to be able to get up on time for work the next day. On Seroquel, I need at least 9 hrs of solid sleep otherwise I feel hung over the next morning. This means no late movies or other activities with friends/boyfriend unless I take it later in the evening and cut the dose which means I probably won't sleep very well. Am also concerned that I may need to increase dose the longer I'm on it. Haven't really had any side effects other than grogginess in the morning and I don't feel safe driving after taking it. Talked to my Dr about getting off eventually & she said its unlikely as I have some mild generalized anxiety and possibly low seratonin levels (as many women over 30 do). Apparently Seroquel is not addicting like Ambien/Lunesta but I would eventually like to sleep on my own and hope its possible down the road. If you start Seroquel don't be surprised if at first it knocks you out for up to 15 hours (try it first on the weekend till you adjust).

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I had a horrible reaction to this drug! I was on it for about 3 weeks. When I got up to the 300mg pill, things started going down hill for me. I had bruses from bumping into things all the time, and it was basically like being drunk and high constantly. It was not fun. The first night I took the 300mg pill I wet the bed cause I was so knocked out I couldn't wake up to go to the bathroom. I went to the doctors because I had slight whiplash from going to an amusement park (while on the med) and not being able to control my head on the roller coasters. When I was in the room my speach was slirred and when I was walking to the waiting room I had to be guided out, and I've been going to this place for years and could probably draw map of it from memory. The PA, nurse, a woman from the front desk who has known me since I was a baby, and my case worker all stopped me before going in the waiting room and told me that I needed to be off this med, because of the effect it was having on me. A different doctor perscribed it for me, and the PA called him and told him I was to taper off Seroquel right away. Getting off the med probably saved my life.

column2: workinggirl, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on some form of antidepressent since 1987. Despite medication, my illness grew from mild depression to a total inability to function in the '00s. Nothing worked until I was put on Seroquel. Like magic, the negative loop that ran and ran in my mind stopped. Yes, I've gained weight (it does seem to trigger late nite eating) and the restless legs sometimes drive me crazy, but I can function again. I even got a job and have been able to keep it! If this had not worked, my doctor was recommending electric shock therapy, so believe me, I am thrilled.  Having taken so many meds over the years, I am convinced that each individuals brain chemistry or whatever you want to call it is as unique as his or her DNA.  What works for me may not work for you.  Side effects that I can tolerate; you may not be able to stand.  But until my doctor tried Seroquel, I was hopeless.  The only thing that kept me from committing suicide was my dogs and not wanting to leave a mess for my family to clean up, either literally or figuratively. Oh, it is also expensive as hell, but I'd pay for it even if I didn't have insurance.  Hopefully, it will become a generic some day soon. Finally, it does make you sleep and sleep and sleep.  I've just had to adjust my life so I can allow 9-10 hours a day for sleep. It is worth it to me.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've tried a lot of antidepressants over the past few years. All the drugs I've tried either didn't work or worked for a bit before they stopped working. Last week, I went to my doctor to follow-up on the Pristiq I've been taking. I told her that some days it seems to help, but other days it seems like I haven't been taking anything.  I also told her that a month or so ago, I was feeling good so I stopped taking it for about 2 weeks and felt great before I crashed. She said it could be that the drug worked its way out of my system, or it could be that I may be bipolar.  I told her that my therapist has had me tracking my moods, and she thinks I may be hypomanic.  My doctor said most people call the doctor when they are feeling down and think they're depressed, so a lot of the time, bipolar disorder gets overlooked.  She had me fill out a questionnaire, and the results showed borderline bipolar disorder. She suggested trying Seroquel. She gave me a starter pack which starts at 50mg on the first day, increases to 100mg on the second day, and goes up to 200mg on the third day.  My doctor said to take the Seroquel at night because it WILL make me drowsy.  I took my first dose (50mg) on Saturday night and woke up on Sunday in a major daze. My husband kept asking me if I was ok. By late afternoon/early evening, I wasn't in a daze anymore. I took my second dose that night (100mg) and woke up on Monday morning again in a daze. I took the morning off work because I was afraid to drive. It almost felt like I had been drinking. That night I took the third dose (200mg). I woke up today feeling very dazed, although I'm coming out of it now around 3:30. I stayed home from work today and called my doctor to see if this was a normal side effect and to ask whether it'll go away. They called me back and said the doctor is calling in a rx for Abilify instead. I hope that helps. The Seroquel has helped with my racing thoughts, but I don't think the daze I've been in is worth it.

column2: Cindy, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I take 300 mg. of seroquel every night at bedtime. 10 yrs ago I took 2400 mg. every night and went from 120 lbs. to  230 lbs. in a year. 18 months ago I started weaning down the mg.'s and am now back to 120 lbs. and maintaining a wellness with 300mg, however, knowing my bipolar so well, sometimes I will take up to 450 mg. knowing that my manic phase is starting to kick in. If I don't take warning to my mania, I will be awake for 3 nights and four days before I completely crash and burn for 3 straight days, waking only to use the bathroom. Seroquel has, what I consider, literally saved my life. Bipolar is a life sentence, unfortunately, but I can maintain a wellness because of it.

column2: lady, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this drug on and off for several years (usually around 75mg/night), primarily for severe anxiety (sometimes a little psychotic). I also have a history of major depression and 2 manic episodes. I do not know if these meds have an effect on my depression because that lifted 4 yrs ago and hasn't returned, and my moods are stable. I suspect that it helps because this is the longest period that I have ever been depression-free. Because of the sedating effects, I definitely feel less anxiety, and so far it has been the only medication that has helped me (I have tried many over the last 14 years). Some anxiety remains, and I still get panic attacks, so I will have to start something else as well. The drug has not been as scary as many of these reviews, but I am on a relatively low dose. Also, don't be turned off by people who complain about the initial side effects. This med takes a long time to stabilize. For the few weeks I was so tired I could barely function, but it was less every day. Now I just need a morning coffee and I'm good. If I miss a dose it is really obvious because my anxiety sky-rockets again. The only side effect of concern is extreme irritability and emotional volatility in the morning that declines as the afternoon approaches. I'll snap at my lovely husband for no reason at all, so have learned to walk away and avoid him when that happens (only about once every few weeks). It's like really bad PMS in the mornings. It's still definitely worth it.

column2: Rachelle S., 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I take a very small dose of Seroquel XR - just 50 mgs - a few hours before bedtime to help with sleep.  I was told this formula (the Seroquel XR) reaches peak levels approx. 4 hours after taking it and have found this to be fairly accurate.  A very important reason that my doctor has me on this drug in addition to Trazodone for slee is it also helps minimize my anxiety and mixed episodes, which is a very good thing!  I was on a higher dose (200 mgs) but found it caused me too much fatigue during the day.  I have had some weight gain with this drug, but that was primarily when I took more, not on this smaller dose.  (The weight gain could also be related to the combination of drugs I take: Depakote XR, Trazodone, Pristiq, Abilify, Klonopin, and Seroquel; so I can't just pin-point it as the Seroquel.)  I did notice that when I first started taking Seroquel it had much more of "an impact" at sedating me then it does now.  The smallest dose could tire me out within about half and hour.  This effect has worn out though now.  Overall, I would say Seroquel is a very effective drug for me.  I know several others that take it (for varying reasons and with varying effects on their energy level) so I will say it's very important with this drug - like all prescriptions - to really find out how it will affect your sleep and energy and why it's being prescribed at the particular dose it is being prescribed.

column1: Mental Disorder with Loss of Normal Personality &amp; Reality
column2: hevans32, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Without Seroquel my quality of life would decrease.  I take Seroquel in conjunction with Zoloft and having been on both now, I cannot imagine going back to the life I had before. When used correctly, these prescriptions are a true life savior. I am being treated for Multiple Personality Disassociative Disorder.  I had to fight to get access to Seroquel. With my medical history I would not have stood a chance with any other prescription.  All the other drugs available to me would have put me in the hospital because of their interactions with everything else in my life.  Seroquel and Zoloft have made my life liveable again. I was taking only Zoloft but my symptons were getting worse and it was not fun.  I do not drink, I do not smoke and I have not had any adverse reactions to my meds together.  It is a wonderful feeling to wake up and know that I am not subject to the noise and fast moving thoughts of my brain.

column9: I no longer take this, but I feel that giving my experience may help.First off it works really, really well for mood stabilization, and if you have insomnia it works really well for that.IMO, it is the second best, with Zyprexa being the first.However, here are the problems.  Sleepiness all the time -though not near as bad Zyprexa.Constant, constant, constant hunger.  Over about four years of taking atypical anti-psychotics.  I went from 190 lbs to 270 lbs.My doctor took me off of it and put me on Lamictil.  Almost, immediately, I started shedding the pounds.  I take other drugs that suppress appetite, but I will say without a doubt that the Seroquel just simply made me way too hungry, and too fat.Look if Lamictil did not exist, it is either taking the Seroquel or having to deal with major depression and dizzying highs.  I would opt to take Seroquel.

column9: I started this medication when I was first diagnosed with Bipolar Disorder 4 years ago.I tried to make it work, but I started to notice several things. First I started falling when I got out of bed. Then I could not catch myself with my arms. Then a few days later I started having tremors and my head would shake like Parkinson's. One day my boss told me he was concerned because I have forgotten things that I have done normally for years. I went to a neurologist and he said that my left side of my body was unstable. After talking with my doctor, he recommended that I switch to Lamictal. Lamictal has been a life saver for me.. that is when I started to truly heal and be able to make decisions. I would say that if you are having symptoms that are worry some and scare you, please talk to you counselors and therapist. You have to find the right combination when you have this disorder.thanksnicole

column2: Ryan in MN, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This medication has been a good addition to my anti-depression battle... helps with anxiety as well as insomnia.  Though i have recently heard that it possibly increases  risk of adult diabetes... hopefully I find it is minimal and I can continue to make progress in finding happiness in life.Certainly the meds do not MAKE us happy, they were very difficult for me to "swallow" when I was first diagnosed with depression and anxiety.  I refused to think I needed to take pill to be happy.  Of course I have learned, they don't create the contentment, but they help us to balance our chemistry to combat the symptoms.  We are all different, and many times the first medications prescribed don't achieve the proper results or even worsen what you are dealing with in the first place.  Dealing with depression on some level for over 15 years myself, I've been through all kinds of presciptions... and just in the past couple years found a combo that is finally effective for me. So if you find the meds you are taking now aren't quite right or simply dont work... keep trying.  It will be very frustrating.Seroquel, along with Lamictal and Lexapro, has helped me to better deal with my depression, anxiety as well as other issues... more effectively than the many other med combination I have tried.  I hope this can help at least one person out there!

column2: bwise, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: seroquel is a very mysterious drug. having been on it for years it seemed to calm many over acting thoughts. of course there is the weight gain but that did not effect my view on this med. i weened off sucessfully, but then put back on for reasons unknown. thats when i realized the outstanding unacceptable side effects. 200mg pill sent me into a nightmare of out of control physical behavior. spasms, jaunting muscles, seizure type episodes, than hospitalization. i decided to look into this med, and discovered the negative side effects highly outstand the possitive in many case studies. this med is at the end of its patent, and is being pushed to patients in high measures. costly, it needs to sell before generics are able to replace it. seroquel barely passed fda regs and i know why. diabeties,extreme weight gain, dillusinal behavior. the sedation aspect as many complain about pales in comparison to how mind altering this drug can be in many,many patients. im underwhelmed, to say the least, this med is rxed to sooooo many. start with very low doseage, and do research. a good alternative is thorzine. it may be oldschool, but its been around so long for a reason. i worry seroquel is pushed too hard on every diagnoses ones dr invents. meds are hugely profitable to many players in this field. by the way, as many know, the makers of seroquel are and have been sued with numerous cases pending. god bless if it works but if you suffer its evil do not be talked into a abusive relationship with this med. long term effects may insue. p.s. sorry for the poor spelling. that i wont blame on seroquel.

column9: I'm now 21 years old. When I was 15 I attempted suicide for the first time, I was sent to a mental facility where they diagnosed me for Bipolar and put me on Seroquel and Lithium. I didn't sleep well, I'd often scream in my sleep and wake myself and everyone around me. The drug made me more confused than anything else, I didn't feel as sad as I did before, but I also couldn't feel happy (unless I was over tired from taking it), it was like I was numb. Nine months later I had a second suicide attempt, I was sent to a different mental health hospital and they replaced my medications with Lexapro, Wellbutrin and Topamax (mostly to help my weight situation). I just got off all my medications last spring, so it's been almost a year now that I've been medication and therapy free. Althought Seroquel can actually treat people, I don't really recommend it for most.
