column2: Do your research first, 45-54 Female  (Patient)
column9: Oh my God-- watch out! This is an extremely POWERFUL medication and unless you have a SEVERE mood disorder, it's over the top! I took only 1/2 the initial dose as prescribed (as recommended by my pharmacist) and I was groggy for 2 days straight -- felt like I was drunk. I have heard the mfr is being sued for not disclosing it causes diabetes and weight gain. Scary drug unless you have a severe problem in my opinion.

column2: patient, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: This medication seems to have been effective at preventing another bipolar episode for me.  However, I have experienced weight gain.  I had gained about 9lbs. previously while taking other meds.  Since switching to only Seroquel at 300mg a day, I have gained 5lbs more.  I think that this weight gain is due mainly to the medication.  I have had difficulty losing any of the weight and keeping it off.  I have never had a problem with being anything but slim before in my life. I have also had problems with grogginess, tiredness, difficulty waking up from sleep, and some difficulty in concentration.  My dose has just been decreased somewhat and I look forward to seeing if that eases my side effects.  It seems to be effective at helping me think positively.  As far as its effectiveness at treating regular depression apart from bipolar disorder, I think it is only somewhat effective at that, as I still have some symptoms of depression. The manufacturer of Seroquel, "AstraZeneca, is trying to get approved for use by people suffering from depression."  I have been on it for about a year, and will think it is very effective if I have had no bipolar episodes 3 to 4 years from now.  The Wall Street Journal online has some good articles about Seroquel and its efficacy and safety.

column2: Zooid, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have been on 1500 mg of Seroquel going on three years. I could not ask for a better treatment. I had an initial weight gain of about 15 pounds, which hasn't gone away. I take the full dose at bedtime. Within 45 minutes I am out and need at least 10 hours of sleep, or else I am so groggy that functioning for the day becomes difficult. About the second year in, my symptoms and minimal side effects began to recede exponentially. I haven't had problems with my blood sugar or have shown signs of diabetes. Constipation was a problem for a long time. One side effect that will not go away is that if I do not take the medication at night I cannot fall asleep and can literally be up for two days without feeling overly tired. So having a few doses in your car, at your friends houses, on you, and places of the like is important. If you miss doses there are noticeable spikes in symptoms that can last several days. Also keep drinking to a minimum. There has been a few times when I drank too much and had to stay in bed for about 15 hours before I had enough energy to crawl out of bed. There is also a very personal side effect with reduction of libido, sexual stimulation and production of semen. I had very weak orgasms paired with no ejaculation. I now have as regular bowel movements and orgasms as I ever had, with the exception that in the mornings, when the drug is still strong in my body, I cannot ejaculate. I am so grateful for this drug, it truly is a miracle. New users, know that it takes time for you to heal. Schizophrenia is a scary illness that tweaks the associations in your brain, it takes a while relearn reality by forging new synapses, Seroquel helped me rely more on facts than delusions and helps me think that my delusions are just that. If you have been on smaller doses for a while and your symptoms have receded little, ask for an increase, it will help. Rely on science and logic to identify your delusions and time and Seroquel will help them dissipate. God speed.

column2: Sleepless, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was Rx's this for sleep.  I had tried Ambien, Restoril & Rozerem which either worked 6 hrs. after taking at bed time or I was just naturally exhausted.  I was staying awake 30-48 hrs. at a time w/ anxirty.  Even if it did fall asleep, any sound could awaken me after 2 hrs. without ability to go to sleep.  Dr. said I desparately needed sleep so she Rx'd this & told me to take 300mg. the 1st time & it would knock a horse out & keep me asleep about 24 hrs. & told my husband not to worry if there was no movement or he couldn't awaken b/c I really needed to sleep.  It worked just as she'd said.  Then I was to take 100mg. ea. night at bedtime.  It will make me sleepy in an hour but I can stay awake if to much anxiety.  But 200mg. will definetly make me sleep.  Problem is that w/ 100-200mg., I usually sleep 10-14 hrs.  If I can wake upp after 8 hrs., I very groggy & can't drive for business.  So I don't take it nightly as I should.  I still have sleep deprivation, but try to take it at least 2-3 times per week on days when I know that I'll be working from home.

column9: I started taking Seroquel over a year ago.  My Dr at the time put me on 200mg a day, and even though I wasn't feeling better, he kept it at that.  In the long run, he ended up up being a terrible Dr, so of course I switched.  My current Dr is awesome, and has me on Seroquel, Klonopin, and Lamictal.  I ended up spending a week in a psychiatric unit with severe anxiety and panic, about 6 months ago, before I was on my current treatment regimen.  After all of that, and during my stay in the hospital, my final dosage is at 600mg per day (50mg morning, 50mg afternoon, 500mg bedtime).  It has worked very well for me, both with my anxiety and my moods.  I haven't had a bipolar cycle in a long time, so in my opinion, Seroquel is an all-around wonder drug! :)

column2: kelzak, 13-18 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: I am the mom of a 13 yr. old with ptsd, spychitso effective dissorder, bi-polar, who has been hospitalized numerous times for suicidal ideation. We have been on abilify, respridol, depecote, lithium, and who knows what else. We have awsome spych nurse but the children's hospital has acted like he is responsibe for his disorder and can controll his actions. Why are some mental health professionals so ignorant?  He has been on this med (300 mg) for a year now and his moods have been fairly stable, for him that is, with the zoloft, clonodine, and topomax coctail he is on. When he started on this med he was like a zombie for months, missed school because I couldn't wake him, and when he was there he fell asleep (still does occasionally)to the point that I was threatened with court action. He has had major weight gain, which continues at 3-5 lbs a month. He is closely monitored, but even with that he is now experiencing health problems that are a direct result of this med. His triglicerides are off the chart, blood-pressure is too low, sugar high, and occasional chest pains. Since we have been through most of the available meds for his dissorders, and he is relative stabile,it has been decided that taking him off of the meds will cause him to crash. I am in the process of working with the doctors, med and pcp, to decide what to do before... I'm not sure what could happen to him, but I was told his situation is dangerous. I know it isn't fair that there are not better meds out there, or ones that the side affects wouldn't kill you, so what is a mother to do? Either way it seems to me that my son is the looser; breakdown- suicide attempts or diabetes, heart disease, or stroke. What would you do?????

column2: Ncontrolofmyowndestiny, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: My doctor prescribed this medication for me and started me out on a low dose. My ending dose is 300 twice per day.  This medication has not helped me at all with any of my issues, in fact, it has made me feel like a zombie throughout the entire day.  I also find that it makes me extremely sleepy so I am not sure why she has prescribed this medication twice a day.  Ive spoken to her numerous times about this issue because it is affecting me staying awake at my job which is not a great thing.  Ive also been experiencing extreme abdominal pain to the point where I could hardly stand up straight.  At first I thought it was gas which causes bloating and pressure but then I found out it was because of this medication.I honestly dont recommend this to anyone due to the ineffectiveness of the product and because it will make you feel like a zombie for at least 99% of your day.  Before I took this medication I actually felt better so I am now at the point of lowering my own dose by cutting my pills in half each day and eventually I will stop taking this medication and seek out a naturopathic or holistic route.I feel that doctors today will prescribe medications to patients without being totally honest about what other products are out there, so we must do our own research.  I have come to the conclusion that doing your own research and finding a doctor who wholeheartedly cares about your well being and is interested and/or willing to try alternatives before giving meds that will make your life less productive can make the difference in solving the problem or having a medical condition that can affect you for the rest of your life.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: After 2 years of using this medication nightly, 500 mg., I began to develop rapid tooth decay at the gumline.  I had several dentists and oral surgeons all inform me that Seroquel was the cause...extreme dry mouth despite drinking nothing but water and milk and brushing, etc.  The decay was so rapid and widesread that after ALL attempts and a small fortune spent, at the age of 38, I had to have ALL of my teeth removed at one time in the hospital!!  I now have a set of $3,000.00 FULL DENTURES!!  I was prescribed this med. for sleep (diagnosed Bi-polar in 1996) along with Restoril, Valium, and Ambien CR!  I have gained a ton of weight, and wake up in the middle of the night (3-4 hours of sleep)!  It's about the strongest thing they can give me for sleep so I still take it nightly.  I really hate this drug!!!  If you take this medication, I STRONGLY recommend you see the dentist every 3 months!!  By the way...Serowuel is NOT approved for the treatment of sleep disorders!!  It is being used improperly!!  If you read the uses, it states that it will make you think clearer and take an active role in everyday life!!  HA!  I feel like I am coming out of anesthesia on this stuff!

column2: jenn157, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Just to start off I read some of the other reviews and was horrified.  I am 36 years old and have been bi-polar since I was a teenager and started taking meds when I was in my 20's I also have schizo trates.  Over the years I have taken every med that is out there on the market and some would work for a little while and then stop working. I have had horrible side effects everything from weight gain, body trimmers so bad I could not stop slobbering and hold a cup of coffee, liver damage, high cholesteral, I can't tell you all the side effects that I have had.I started seeing a new doc and she suggested that we try seroquel and I was at my wits end because I did not want to end up back in the mental hospital I just wanted something that was going to work.  I started taking it and everyone said they could see a difference in me that was for the good I was like my old happy self again.  I have been able to stop taking the anti depesants and the sleeping pills and the anti anxity pills. This drug has made a world of differance for my life I am able to get up and do things, be with my family and friends and I am happy.  Not all days are good mind you I still have some times where the anger comes out so I think I might need to increase the dose but all in all this drug has been a life saver for me.

column2: mountain mama, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I've been using Effexor 300mg & Lamictal 200mg but unable to get to sleep or stay asleep for more than 2 hrs @ a time. And my sleep cycle is backwards - awake all night and sleep all day. These meds have been wonderful but my continuing depression had escalated sleep disorders and the remaining depression from which I could not dig myself out despite the addition of a full spectrum light box I felt I needed something else if it were available.  Seroquel 50-150mg has done the trick for me for my lingering bi-polar & clinical depression.  All 3 meds + my light box have worked wonders for my 'dark night of the soul' and for my insomnia types.  Now I'm hoping to get my sleep hygiene back on track & wake up w/ a better outlook for the day. Or at least an outlook that is realistic. I'm also a Type II diabetic, controlled by diet & exercise & I have found that Seroquel does, in fact, raise my blood sugar.  My FBS ranges are now 109-118, but my 2hr post prandial sugars are in my range of 120-135. Hope this is helpful.

column2: TiNK, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: My OpinionSeroquel good for:Excellent Sedative, Controls Emotional Instability--which is exactly what it should do.Bad:irritability, shaking, withdrawal, weight gain, grogginess, forgetfullness, slight angerI've been on and off and back on Seroquel since March '08. For someone like me who was suffering from paranoia, panic attacks, anxiety, and drasitic mood changes from being extremely happy to unbearably sad, the amount of sleep I was getting was about .8 hours per night.  My first dose of 50mg knocked me out within 20min.  I have never felt better. My doctor had me gradually step up to 200mg within a week and I honestly felt better aside from the grogginess. I had no mood swings, I wasn't feeling anxious, and best of all, my general fears subsided and I was able to gradually sleep without the light on. As a 26 year old woman, I was really happy about that last one. Those were the good things.  As for the not so great things, I realized that the reason I wasn't having those terrible feelings was because the Seroquel had me so tired, that I didn't have the chance to be worried, sad, or frightend. I would wake up and just be dragging. I also noticed that I was extremely thirsty, which I confused for hunger, thus the weight gain of 10lbs. But I was lucky enough to catch on to the weight gain factor and control that with plenty of water. BTW, it dries out your skin so if you have oily skin Seroquel is a plus! The worst side effect I've experienced is anger. Since being on this medication I become angry much easier than I used to.  In fact, I never used to get very angry, just sad.  Now I feel angry and irritated at small things.  I mentioned it to my doctor and told him I wanted to get off.  When I stopped taking it I experienced terrible withdrawal.  And this was only after a month of taking it.  nausea with vomiting, depression, etc. It was terrible.  I am now back on it to control my anxiety because I haven't been properly diagnosed.

column9: on it for almost 2 years. took about a year for the seroquel "morning hangover" to go away. now i look at it as one the BEST sleep med. out in less than an hour.sleep the whole night through with out waking up. feel GREAT when i wake up. i did not realize how much of a sleeping problem i had. for the first time i can sleep 6-8 hours at a time. and straight through. still take it during the day. sometimes i do find it still "knocks" me out, but i get through it and im fine an hour or two later. this medication is great as a sedative. as a college student also with extreme ADHD i struggle quite a bit to try and maintain an A average, and seroquel has really helped me from completely loosing it when i feel overwhelmed or frustrated. i no longer walk out of classes crying due to stress or bite my teachers face off. im normally not one to do this. in fact i cant stand disrespectful students. i have had VERY good teachers, but the bad one are such a trigger for my mania. i take an extra amount before attending their classes.

column2: feelgood, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Been prescribed almost every anxiety med available. Unfortunately after so long the dose has to keep increasing until you reach the highest dose. Then you repeat the process with another med to take its place. My last med was Paxil for my anxiety. So mutually my doctor and I wanted to try Seroquel. Within one week I feel wonderful other than the slight dizziness and grogginess in the morning. I am currently on 200 mg. By reading these posts that are the same situation as myself I am going to decrease my dose in half and take when I get home from work, not before I go to bed to try to alleviate these 2 side effects that I am experiencing. But for ME this med is wonderful. I am completely stress free and enjoy life in a totally new light in just one week of taking this med . So something tells me Im taking too high a dose for my body to handle. I will keep experimenting until I find the right dosage. I would also like to add that everyone is different . Not every med works the same for everyone. You shouldnt "slam" a drug if it doesn't work for you personally. It could be a life saver to someone else and their family.

column2: TangJie, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been on this medication for about a week. My Dr. had me start with 50mg at bedtime and that first morning I could barely get out of bed. After another dose of 50mg the next day it wasn't as bad and on the 3rd night I increased it to 100mg. I was still having trouble with being sleepy for a few hours after getting up but the rest of the day was a big improvement in my mood. My wife even commeted on how I seemed to be doing better. My Dr. said I should try to work up to 200mg-300mg at bedtime so I incresed it to 150mg and the side effects didn't get any worse so I plan to go up to 200mg after a couple of more days at 150mg. I did notice that I seem to get the munchies throuogh out the day, but now that I'm more aware of the weight gain problem I've been able to resist the urge to eat and so I hope to avoid that problem. The overall benefit to this drug seems to be alot more calmness in my personality and and alot less anger and homocidial thouhgts. I think it is working well for me. I would recommend starting at the low doasge and slowly increasing until you get the results you need. It does tend to make you feel hung over the next day so I started taking earlier in the evening, like a couple of hours before bedtime and that seems to have resolved that problem as well.

column2: Anonymous, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have Bipolar 1 and I am 16 years old.  I was diagnosed February my freshmen year of high school and they put me on Lamictal in June.  It treated some of my symptoms in the first month: extreme interest in sex, delusional thinking, depression, and others I can't even remember because they stopped.  But I added Seroquel last May (October now).  Stress and bad sleeping patterns set me off, and I am pretty good about recognizing when I am about to go through an episode or what state I am in.       I take a dose of 150 Lamictal (2x a day), 200 Seroquel (2x day).  I was a little out of shape when I started Seroquel, so its side effects were strong, especially dizziness (I would sit down for a long time and when I got up, I lost my balance, couldnt see because my vision would go white.  And I usually fell down or smacked into a wall, not fun...).  I dont like the dizziness and this started the day after I began taking it.  Being in good physical shape can really help.   Seroquel also causes me to have episodes that I call panic attacks that started when I increased it.     A trypical panic attack:  I have trouble thinking and functioning mentally.  Im a vegetable.  And when I am trying to do a certain thing, like math, it frustrates me and then I loose it.  I start to cry, my breathing gets messed up, and I cant put 2 and 2 together to save my life.  Someone will try to ask me a question and instead of answering, I start crying and breathing fast, my heart-rate skyrockets, I repeat phrases like I dont know because I cant think and Im completely terrified.  This is set off by stress and a change in sleeping patterns.        Im not sure if Seroquel is a good thing even though my doctor thinks it is.  But even though my doctor disagrees, I can honestly pinpoint some bad things to this medication.  If it works for you, great, if it doesnt, we might have something in common.

this drug has worked very well for me i take 600mgs a day ya its alot but its what helps me , yes the side effects are hard to nget use to in the beging but they get etter i dont sleep without it although that starts to were off fast everyones diffrent yes. for me it helps my deppresion go away to a point but lets be honest  meds help but we cant get away from all of the deppressin best of luck to you all.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This medication has been quite effective in treating my depression and anxiety. One of the side-effects was unbearable when I first started it. Excessive tiredness, dizziness, and forgetfulness resulted from larger doses (300-400mg). I gave up on the medicaiton at first, but then I recently started to split the pills into 100 mg pieces and am taking them throughout the day. I can now handle the lower level of tiredness and I can actually stay awake and more alert, although I am also occasionally left to drinking caffenated drinks to help with my energey level.  Extreme tiredness(zombie-effect) appears to be a common side-effect. To combat this I suggest trying smaller doses and taking them throughout the day instead of once a day. In the two months since being on this I have seemed to have just recently built up a bit of a tolerance, thus the zombie-effect has lessened.  I have also gained 3-4 pounds  since starting this medication.  I seem to be hungry more often.  Watch out for this as well and try to start or continue exercising. I do get some other side-effects, however they are minor in comparison to the ones listed above.

column1: Mental Disorder with Loss of Normal Personality &amp; Reality
column2: Amythyst, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Fortunately, seroquel was my blessing...For many years I suffered from severe depression which caused me to hear voices that weren't there...I also suffered from ADD, Social Anxiety Disorder, and Insomnia....I was put on adderall in 2000 to treat my ADD...I am a very petite woman with a very high metabolism so gaining weight for me was REALLY hard to do...I am 5'2'' and I have never reached 100 lbs in my lifetime...Due to the adderall and my paranoia I lost ALOT of weight...I went from 80 lbs to 68 lbs...I was taken off the adderall immediately and put on seroquel...I started taking 25 mg a night, not only did I gain weight (I weighed 96 lbs) but, I slept and I no longer heard those voices. I weened myself off of seroquel due to concerns...Now, I regret it...Seroquel really helped me with my anxiety...it made me less nervous in different situations and made me more comfortable with myself...and I kept my weight up....it also helped with my insomnia...Without it, I am a mess...the paranoia returned...I can't sleep again...(I am back on the adderall again) I was taking Straterra but, due to personal reasons like the seroquel I stopped taking it...I lost weight again because of the adderall...I was taking Lunesta to help me sleep but, I broke out in hives and my behavior and mood swings were worse than ever...I suffered loss of memory which never happens...Adderall is not meant for petite adults that are underweight...(I am perfectly healthy and eat like a horse...always have...I never had a eating disorder and I still don't) mental illness is a horrible thing...I suffered from panic attacks and anxiety since I was in grade school due to endless amount of harassment from classmates and teachers...I no longer have depression either...:)

column9: first drug to work for me.  battled depression and insomnia 15 years.  tried many others that didn't work.

column2: ellebee67, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Been on a ton of dif meds for Bi-polar disorder (rapid cycling), this one seem to work the best so far.  I don't have the weight gain and it's the best night sleep ever! I have accidentally skipped a dose or two and couldn't sleep for a couple of days (50+hrs). I fall asleep fast and stay put for 9+ hrs. I did have a hard time at first w/waking but now I am learning to take it earlier (which is difficult, I work 2nd shift), and get up earlier.  I tend to stay awake the rest of the day as well.  No tiredness through out the day.  But if I take it and I am not in bed, I do tend to feel a bit "drunk". I did my homework a bit before taking.  I knew a lot of people said something about weight gain. So knowing that before hand, I curbed my normal eating habits and changed them into healthier choices.  I have increased my activity level as well.  All in all I have lost 12 lbs.  My moods have leveled.  I am a bit more organized. And I am trying to be a bit more hands on with my kids (ages 16 & 11).  I also picked up a hobby which normally I would never do.  I will write back if I have  down side, or an episode. I hope you found this helpful and I hope it helps you see a different side to this medication.  Good Luck.

column1: Bipolar I Disorder with Most Recent Episode Mixed
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have used a number of meds in the past, my DR. picked a great combo.  I have been taking 200mg of lamictal in the morning and 50mg of seroquel at night.  Sure it may have different effects on people, but for me, it is amazing.  I actually feel stable. I haven't felt this normal  in. . . I don't know.  Forever.  If you are just starting.  Give it a chance.  Let it get in your system and do its thing.  Nothing is going to be a miracle overnight.  I had been on Effexor for three years.  I am still on it.  We are going to start my taper at end of September.  I am a little worried, but I know  that what I sm taking now is working. If this med doesn't work for you.  Don't give up.  You and your DR. will find the right one for you.  Everybody is different.  GOOD LUCK EVERYONE!!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: After a week in the hospital for server depression, weight loss, anxiety, and whole slew of other mental problems I was sent to the supposedly the "best" psychiatrist. All this guy would do was dope me up on different meds, but he was most successful when he prescribed me the seroquel.  I only weigh 102 lbs but instead of starting on low dosage I prescribed on a 100mg pill.  I was suppose to take it every morning with other medication.  I could not remember the day, I would pass out, in class, driving.  I try taking only 50mg but my day still had felt surreal. Eventually I decided to use it as a sleeping pill, it worked, but i never got up.  Or when I did get up I felt as though I was suffering from a hangover.  Unless you are looking to be a zombie or sleeping beauty,  I would recommend this pill.  But if you are trying to start enjoying life and becoming part of it STAY AWAY!

column9: My Bipolar 18 yr old niece was hospitalized due to being suicidal and was put on this. In a 1-2 wk. period (while in hospital) they brought her up to the full dose. When she went back to high school, she had what they call Word Loss where she would raise her hand to give her interpretation of a poem and she would have trouble expressing what she meant to say and it was very embarrassing for her. She almost got in an argument with the teacher and she is not the type to do that.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: A couple weeks ago, I had a manic episode with psychotic features. I was on Geodon and Lithium when it occured. At the hospital I was tapered off of the Geodon and started on the seroquel. It wasn't until I had reached the 600mg at night dosage that I was able to finally sleep eight hours. However, I do wake up often during the night. I have been on the 600 mg dose for over a week and my psychotic symptoms are finally starting to fade. Because of Seroquel, I wake up drowsy, foggy, and have a dry mouth. Also, the severe perpetual hunger caused by the seroquel has just about driven me crazy. I am determined not to gain weight on Seroquel so I am toughing out the hunger and watching what I eat for the three meals a day I do eat. So in summary, the seroquel took a little while to accomplish its task and its side effects are bothersome. I am hoping that the side effects will disapear once I become accustomed to this drug. I don't know how long that is going to take because with Geodon it took three to four months before the side effects disapeared. I don't know if I can be severely hungry for that long.

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)

Sometimes I stay awake right through it, sometimes I wake up all night with dry mouth. One day I want to increase my dose to 200 and another day I want to stop taking it all together.

I wish I stuck with my gut instinct, I took Seroquel for less than 2 weeks and my depression worsened, suffered from depersonalization (which had never occurred before), I felt nervous/shaky without physically shaking, and zombie-like and very negative. I noticed that I had trouble handling small problems, I took them as the end of the world. I also noticed that my blood circulation was impaired, my hands would go numb, more so right when I'd woke up. I can tell it has still not left my system, I just don't feel like myself. I know this is a good medication, it is just not the right drug for me and I feel it was prescribed in bad judgment to me especially with hypertension. I also gained nearly 7 lbs in the two weeks.

lblvn, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: After 14 months of trying EVERY medication under the sun for my insomnia, I switched doctors and he immediately started me on Seroquel. That night was the FIRST night I slept more than 2 hours total in 14 months! I actually slept for 10 hours, and I rested, not just closed my eyes. I had been going, non stop, for 4 and 5 days in a row with a max of 4 hours of sleep TOTAL! It has been a life saver for me! I did find out the hard way, though, don't take seroquel and codeine at the same time... I took a teaspoon of cough syrup with codeine when I was sick and my pulse was BOUNDING and at 155bpm for over 3 hours. I fell asleep convinced I was not going to wake up. MY husband sat up and checked my pulse constantly for HOURS... It finally came down to 110 after 6 hours. NEVER AGAIN!!! I was given 100mg to take but I MUST have 12 hours to devote to sleeping if I take that much.  I get by with 8 hours with taking 50mg. It seriously saved my life, and my marriage... I'm not quite as moody and "snappy" because I'm not exhausted.

column2: pill geek, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: Been off and on this med since 1999. First, 200mg a night, then down to 25mg a night and then up to 50mg a night, I stopped it and tried to switch to Topamax---BIG mistake. Topamax made me very ill. For the last two weeks I was having severe abdominal pain, which no diagnostic test could diagnose - abdominal and vaginal ultrasound. I couldn't eat. I stopped the Topamax per physician's orders, and just started back on 50mg of Seroquel at night. Today was the first day in a very long time my stomach did not hurt as bad - meaning this medication works for my ANXIETY, my IBS. I was wondering why I was becoming so restless and irritable during the days, I think I finally figured out that Seroquel helps my anxiety and I take 50mg for sleep. I tend to be an addict, so will not take Lunesta, Ambien or the like. I also take Suboxone and Librium, and I have been able to cut down on the Librium since starting back on Seroquel, it really helps my PTSD symptoms in the morning - I was wondering why I was getting panic attacks when I woke up - - because the Seroquel had been out of my 'system' for over 2 months. The only thing I worry about is that my heart tends to beat irregular, and now my physician believes I am pre - diabetic. I could lose a good 30 Lbs., but I also eat tons of veggies and ride my bike as much as possible. I do not sit and watch soap operas and eat Ding Dongs. I haven't gained much weight from Seroquel, my eating sugar is to blame for my weight gain. Interesting how I had to play doctor to find out why I was feeling so horrible - I thought I had something seriously wrong with my abdominal pain. Still not sure what effect this medication has on our hearts.....hotstuff70 at peoplepc.com

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this med for almost 11 yrs. for borderline personality disorder. I started it about 2 days after it was approved and during my third trip to the psych ward. I did have the low blood pressure/fainting if I didn't lie down asap side effect for about 3 yrs. I still take the same 150 mg dose every night. If I go without it (due to pharmacy or holiday hour confusion) I get really cranky and paranoid and confrontational. I used to have really vivid dreams and found that Effexor made the dreams so vivid that everything was in extremely bright color and I could touch, taste, smell. Really too psychedelic and I felt so tired when I woke up. I'm on Lexapro now.I would suggest Dialectical Behavior therapy as well as medication. I can function much more normally now and blend in socially so to speak without behaving like an a** and feeling like everyone is against me.

column2: Rocketpop, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: An acute improvement from Zyprexa. Started at 75 and currently at 800 mg spread out daily. Mania and depression are both aided satisfactorily. Side effects that were part of Zyprexa are drastically lessened: increased appetite, hypersomnia, and cognitive hindrance are wonderfully diminished in comparison. Nasal congestion has been a significantly annoying problem, particularly with sleep. Tiredness is also noticeable, but not worse than with Zyprexa. Strangely, effects can be erratic: a dosage that often quickly puts to sleep can have a much more muted effect the night afterwards and has required me to take 50-100% more to fall asleep, without the presence of caffeine, chocolate or other stimulants. This odd inconsistency has been constant since day one of taking it.

column9: Quote:My son is 9. He has been on ths md. for 6 yrs. now . His Dr. recently uped his med from 2oomg. to 400mg. He has been having trouble adjusting to the change. He walks in to walls, and is always late for school. His Dr. wont listen and tells me I am not a Dr. they know what he needs... Do the parents have any say ever? I was also tol that if I refused to give it to him, I could be charged W/ child endangerment. H ow can this be write for my son to be lathargic all the time? can any on help??? thanks, worried in IL.You do not have to give your child a medication that you do not think is right for your child. Your child is not in danger (like a child with juvenile diabetes who you dont help administer insulin, that IS prosecutable, youre scenario is not) If your doctor is not listening you need, absolutly need to switch doctors asap. you have to be extremely careful with what you put in your body. My husband whos 26 is still paying the price for medications he took when he was a child. They were new and innovative and didn't know the long term effects, well... now he's suffering from them.  If you feel something is wrong, do something about it. Get someone to listen. You only have one body. and you have to speak up for your childs.

column2: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Caregiver)
column9: My 17 y.o. daughter was on this med for nearly a year.  Dr's had maintained the benefits out weigh the side effects.  Not so in her case.  She has what we are told may be irreversible tremors.  She had severe loss of appetite and nauseau, which in turn she responded by refusing this med on many occasions.  She was admitted to a different facility and they immediately stopped Seroquel and began Risperdal-M, a disintegrating tablet and also Cogentin to combat the tremors. It is important to keep in mind that bad side effects play an important role in treating disorders, especially in teens when these side effects are visual to others and they are prone to reject meds if they associate negative experiences with treatment. Listen to your loved ones concerns regarding their treatment and know that ill side effects can outweigh the benefits.  There are other options.

column2: bent&amp;broken, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: This is only my 3rd day using seroquel but this is the first day in many years that I have wanted to wake up.After a couple days figuring out the effects I am currently taking a 50mg at @ 11AM then another 50mg @ 9pm wich helps me sleep,although I do take 1/2 a 5mg tab of Valium before bed.I also have supplemented with the Valium in the daytime when I start stressing.I havent experienced much additional appetite or weight gain yet,I have put on about 30lbs over the winter just due to boredom while recuperating from a torn ACL.A have taken coctails of Prozac,Welbutrin, Zoloft,Trazadone,Valium,you name it,but had some very unsettling side effects from being on so many drugs.Seroquel is the first single drug that covers most of my symptoms.For today I will say it is a Godsend,for it's the first day I really felt like I wanted to live until tomorrow.

column2: Nay, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was diagnosed with Bipolar II in August 2008. I had severe aggravation, anxiety, couldn't relax, insomnia, irrated easily, most of the time isolated and couldn't work to boot. I went to a psychiatric nurse practioner and she started putting me on Lamictal and klonapin for sleep. After two times trying Seroquel, the second time was the better. I think the Lamictal had to balance my mood first and my body got used to that way of functioning, more calm. My sleep is much better, can sleep through the night at 50mg at bedtime. I feel so relaxed during the day and more confident I can get through my days. Not inhaling alot to relax. No weight gain yet, but I am excercising regularly and eating right. Please don't give up on medications as Seroquel might be helpful especially with sleep. You,ll know right away with the sleep. I know we are all different and we all need different dosages or meds. but it's nice to know that Seroquel works fast for sleep and in my case three days to see the calmness. I have read so many reviews, and thank you to all who have helped me find Seroquel with yuor inspiring stories.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I took this drug and it turned me into a complete zombie!!! I slept for almost 24/7. I started on the starter pack (25 mgs, then 100, then 200, then finally 300 mgs) at night time. When I was awake I was a monster!!! I flipped out over anything and everything! I was in constant state of panic/anxiety and paranoid beyond belief. I had no appetite what-so-ever. A week later had gone by after starting this medication I was on the phone with my dad and I felt like I was a magnet and my entire body felt like it was going to puddle onto the floor. I got off the phone with him, called the ER and told them what was going on. They told me to tell the person who put me on the med to take me off and to find something else. My heart felt like it was going to explode. I collapsed on the bed and passed out. I woke up sometime later and found myself not being able to move, talk, nothing! I could hear my heart. It was so slow it was pausing at times. I was scared as hell. I couldn't move, but I had tears freely falling from my face. Woke up hours later, went to a counseling appt (not the nurse that gave me the med). She saw how I was and was amazed at what that med did to me. My speech was slow, it gave me amnesia (i honestly had convo's on my cell and never knew i had them!!!!) It was a horrible experience and will NEVER go back to that drug again!!!!!

column9: I was started on this medication Seroquel after a manic-depressive episode. I was in the middle of cycling phases. The M.D. put me on 100mg and after 3 days bumped to 200mg. Always question your doctor about what they are using this medication for(diagnosis) and request that you start low & graually go up as needed. As a patient you have a right to ask questions. If the doctor gets offened, then you need a new doctor. I left a program because I felt the doctors were not listening, but always telling. Now I will find a new program. I do recommend education via mental health facilities. You will learn more at a facility than at most doctors offices, unless you find the best doctor ever, but don't count on it!

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have been on 300 mg of seraquel for about 3 months, but because the dose is way too strong, I take 1/3. I used to be a trim size four but as a result of the medication and the increase in appetite, I am now a size ten. Though it does help me sleep, it sometimes make me feel dizzy and nauseaus. If I happen to get up in the middle of the night, I bump into things. Recently while getting up in the middle of the night to use the restroom, I hit my head,but I was so groggy I didn't realize I had hurt myself. My vision has blurred, I sometimes get pain in my body when I'm sleeping and I wake up in the morning feeling sluggish and drugged. On some days I have such a hard time shaking the fogginess off that I am completely withdrawn.Additonally it has made me severely constipated. Also with the weight gain, I'm extremely concerned about becoming diabetic. My mother was bi-polar too and she became diabetic from her medication-a year after acquiring diabetes she passed away. It's extremely frusterating to have to choose between your mental health and your physical well being. I'm sure that seraquel works fine for some, but it is not a medication I would recommend.

column2: pyper1, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I've lived with schizoaffective disorder for over 20 years and I have been on a vast and complete gamut of various medications. Seroquel has been the med that has given me the most competent help so far, as being able to live my life in  what one would consider the highest quality terms of every day living. As compared to any other med I've used. Yes, there are some effects one must watch, as Seroquel does have the tendecy to cause an excitement of the Pancreous. One can adjust to this possible deficency, by the avoidance in consumtion of the amounts of sweets and or sugar one uses.This is benefit to the overall health for the person who is currently using Seroquel, as excess sugars are a huge problem in our diets today as a whole. Any elimination of such excess sugars is a win/win senario with one who is currently using Seroquel.If one continues to use excessive amounts of sugars in their diets, this can have the effective disabling of ones pancreatic functions by leading to Diabetic conditions, which are as I noted earlier easily avoided by strictly limiting your sugar intake.
much better lifestyle and no bad mood swings do not hit wife anymore and we love each other again

column2: bjr28, 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Although my psychiatrist loves this drug, I found it totally ineffective. Moreover, it gave me constant headaches, slow (but persistent) weight gain, and, perhaps most importantly, it made me sleep all day, which rendered my totally dysfunctional.  I have found Abilify (surprising, I know) and Zyprexa to be much better at treating the positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia, and, most importantly, allowing me to operate at a high level of functionality.  Given that all the anti-psychotics work differently, it's worth a try, but I have found Abilify and Zyprexa to be superior drugs.  In Seroquel's defense, however, I have heard that (for most people) the sleepiness wears off after a few weeks; it just didn't for me.  I would talk to your doctor and do some research about the other anti-psychotics (Abilify, Geodon, Risperdal, and Zyprexa) before taking Seroquel.  Lastly, be careful at first b/c you will not be able to drive or operate machinery &c. &c.

My only fear now is I may have to stop taking it because we want children.  It's a good drug for some, just start small and adjust as needed by talking to your doctor.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: i have been taking this for 1 &1/2 years.I also take effexor.I divide my life in 2, pre and after this med. My life has changed so dramatically, in a good way!I can process info,am not in a state of panic and self loathing, and confusion.Now that my thinking has cleared up, i must face the crazy things i did in the past,and the troubles i have had all my life, it is very difficult and sad.My illness ran my life before, not me.I am grateful that i can now stand back and really think about things ,big or small, the medicine allows me to have the luxury that"normal" people have all the time.I am 55 and for the first time in my life i get to hear the words in songs I've heard for 50 years, so simple yet a profoundly different experience,as i was never able to comprehend even such basic stuff before.The "psychotic" stuff has slowed down too. It's great to be able to sleep every night.I tried easing up on the effexor, but immediately had the constant body pains that i had all my life, so the combo is what works.I no longer have  my physical,emotional and mental life filled with confusion and pain.Weight gain has been the biggest problem, i have gone from 150 to 180!!!,a dry mouth, and receding gums concern me.Also a series of skin infections on my feet continuously.I sometimes have bad heartburn, but perhaps this is also due to weight gain.I am rarely sick, have fewer colds or headaches than before.I cannot take the summer heat, and find that sweating comes with any physical exertion at all.I am concerned about raised sugar levels, I seem to crave sweets.I also am thirsty a lot.And finally, the price is outrageous-$760 for one of the seoquel prescriptions. My health ins. does not pay for scripts, but was the only ins.I could find that covered mental health.My health ins. is my biggest monthly expense, more than house etc.It is clearly discriminatory for those of us needing meds and mental health coverage.Despite the side effects, I cannot imagine living without it.

column2: LibertyRayne, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I agree this med makes me very sleepy... at least for the first week or so. I'm newly diagnosed as bi-polar and this is the first treatment we tried because of I've also PTSD nightmares/flashbacks. I have to say I actually sleep now, of course, but after the first week of taking the med I'm not drowsy during the day and I feel stable. I've had one panic attack in two weeks, two "manic" episodes in a month lasting less than a day each, and my depressive days have been cut dramatically! If you're looking for a miricle drug, there isn't one. This isn't for everyone. It can't work for everyone-- nothing can. It sucks, get over it. But I'd recommend trying it to any one with bipolar or PTSD with the caution to take a week off and adjust fully to the new med. I'm now taking 200 mg at night and 25 mg three times in the day time and I work a full 40 hours a week.

column2: knightsaber1, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I had to be hospitalized just to get off of Zyprexa, which was causing negative side effects and withdrawal upon my trying to switch from it. Personally, I would recommend Seroquel as an alternative to Zyprexa for anybody. The side effects are a bit similar, but not nearly as acute or inhibiting. If you're considering Zyprexa for a psychiatric disorder, Seroquel is probably a much wiser choice. It's a more advanced drug, and it doesn't impair your cognitive abilities or motivation like the older ones do. It will increase your appetite, but I've found that side effect to decrease over time. The biggest problem, though, is that it will be very hard for you to wake up the first few mornings as your system gets used to it.

column2: Joanne, 75 or over Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver)
column9: My mother is 92 years old and has been taking the lowest dose of Seroquel at an assisted living residence for the last few years. Her many years of not being treated for a multitude of psychotic behaviors while living alone (paranoia, racing thoughts, aggressive behavior, insomnia, delusions of granduer,etc.) has vastly improved with Seroquel and she became a rationale and caring human being and was able to sleep well for the first time in her life. She did gain weight, but was under-weight to start with, and has developed swallowing problems and has had to change her diet.Her doctor just stopped her dosage 2 weeks ago (cold turkey) after no negative symptoms presented, and she has just ended up in the ER and psychiatric unit at the hospital after becoming verbally and physically abusive to her caregivers and was removed from the facility kicking and screaming. The doctor has stated that he thought that since she was on such as low dose, she didn't need the medication anymore. We are investigating the whole situation, but are stunned that her doctor would remove her from the drug when she had been doing so well on it.

column2: phoenixgirlie, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I've been on seroquel for the last couple of months. I take 200mg along with 1500mg of lithium, 30mg of abilify, 200mg of trazodone and 150mg of lamictal. I guess the way it works for me is that it knocks me out for about 18 hours a day. I can't function while on it, since I feel so groggy and continuously tired. Half of the time, I can't even open my eyes. It does help with the sleep, otherwise I'd be up for days at a time. But as far as the mania, it hasn't helped me much yet. Maybe because I'm always sleeping and the time that I am awake, I'm irritated, moody and very anxious. Maybe it will get better in time though.

column2: FairyGlenn, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: As with any medication, it interacts with each person differently.  I have been treated for Severe Clinical Depression for 20 years I started on Seroquel 2.5 years ago after I found my usual antidepressant losing it's effectiveness. I have never had the "manic" or "up" side of Bipolar disorder but have found this RX effective in treating my symptoms. Finding the right dose is always trial and error but I find that those who don't have a positive result haven't given the medicine an appropriate amount of time to work. Yes, when I started taking Seroquel I was a walking zombie for a week but with each subsequent dose I felt the side affects less and less until they were gone.

column2: Jason, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I've been taking this medication along with Concerta for about 6 years now for bipolar disorder and adhd. My moods swings are less severe now and I'm not as angry anymore. I'm more patient too. I do on occasion still have my "bad days" though. I take 100mg before bed and actually sleep whereas before I'd frequently go days without rest. Higher dosages gave me severe RLS and had me feeling cold one minute and hot the next. It also made my eyes extremely sensitive to light. On the 100mg dosage my 2 complaints are weight gain of around 30 pounds and a strange congestion of my upper sinuses that leaves me breathing through my mouth at night.If I forget to take a dose I will not sleep at all. I'm scared of the possibility of this medication causing diabetes as my father is a brittle diabetic. I eat very low fat meals, little sweets and drink only diet soda which has kept my blood sugar levels normal so far.

column2: AliveAtLast!!, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Following my Psychiatrists advice, I started with a beginning dose of 25mg per day and ramped up to 600mg per day within 2 weeks.  I have currently been on 600mg for about 13 months.  I went from being a hopeless 30+ year alcoholic (apparently self medicating bi-polar II), with frequent in-patient treatments, to a recovering alcoholic sober for over a year now.  I have no doubt that Seroquel saved my life.  I went from the brink of suicide to the most "together" I've felt in my 53 years.  The only thing different with my alcoholic treatment strategy this time was the Seroquel.  I've noticed a couple of posts saying Seroquel has some "street value" for drug abuse.  Hmmm....I would think that is the case only if you wanted to SLEEP on the street.  This stuff puts you in snooze mode, so take it before bed.  I have noticed absolutely no surreal or feeling high characteristics.  It does give you hunger fits, so you need to religiously follow Doctor's instructions and get regular blood work to test glucose levels, cholesterol and triglycerides.  You also need to work a responsible weight maintenance program.  Not too hard to do when your head is screwed on straight like Seroquel has done for me.  My anxiety level went from an extremely high level to what I perceive as low.  The world is now a pretty good place to live.  I should note that I am also on 325mg Effexor XR (SSRI) per day (past 5 years) and have no idea if the combination has somehow given me outstanding results. All I can say is Seroquel RULES for me.  Your mileage may vary.

column2: Black Rainbow, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I was given Seroquel to see if it would help with bipolar depression and a sleeping disorder. I would be up all night and sleep in the day. I guess you could say I was nocturnal. I had pretty much dealt with that for years, though. I was diagnosed Bipolar without the extreme manic episodes. This medicine is not bad, I had no problems except sleepiness, and extreme hunger. This is technically an anti-phychotic drug, but popular and used quite frequently. I would suggest starting out on a very small dose, say 25 mg. & work up from there. I was taking 300 mg a day, but then stopped the medicine for a while, and now use occasionally at night. 25 mg knocks me out now. You do get used to it in higher doses if you up your mgs slowly and take it everyday. But, beware of the side effect of hunger because if it's not nailed down YOU WILL EAT IT! (oh, but not so bad in small doses)

column2: Beth, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Took my first dosage (25 mg) at 9 p.m.  Awoke at 7 a.m. the next day, feeling very groggy, slightly nauseous & sensitive to light.  I lost consciousness about 7 minutes after waking up, likely due to a drop in blood pressure.  The fall resulted in serious injuries (cuts and bruises) and a concussion, and a trip to the ER.  I would advise starting treatment on a day you can devote to assessing how you react.  I personally was advised by ER Doc to discontinue.

column9: Have taken anywhere from 200-800mg for manic phase of bipolar disorder over the last 4 years along with every other drug out there known to man. It is the ONLY thing that helps me sleep at night and after many years of me working with the drugs I finally have my disorder under control. The only downside is that I was diagnosed with diabetes this year and the only cause we can come up with is prolonged use of Seroquel. I have it well under control now and it may go away if I am able to come off the drug but I'm willing to live with it for now, I am that pleased with this drug! I have been to the dark side of bi-polar and I am not returning! Hope this helps!

column2: BlueHedgehog, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I'm a high schooler who began taking Seroquel when I was in eighth grade for depression, anxiety, and insomnia. When I started taking it, I thought it was a miracle drug: it got me to sleep quickly (which covers anxiety and insomnia) and I was to groggy to feel anything, including sadness.  It sort of worked at first, but steadily lost its effectiveness at zoning me out, and its appeal. Over the course of six weeks, I gained 60 pounds;I was eventually diagnosed with pre-diabetes. This medication did NOT help me, I thought I was doing better because I was in a daze most of the time, and too groggy to realize what it was doing to both my physical and mental health. I go to a small theraputic school, and of all the kids there who have taken it, I have never heard of any good it has done for teens. I'm now on other medications, and struggling to lose the weight Seroquel left me with. This medication tampered with my memory, my health, my personality, and my mood.

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: My doctor was afraid that my 30 year use of Haldol would produce uncontrollable facial movements.  She prescribed increasing doses of seroquel, ending at 200 mg per day.  After a few weeks I developed targives diskenesia with drastic lip and tonque thrusting as well as leg thrusting.  My wife reported this to the doctor who was sure that this would abate after I used seroquel for a period of time.  Luckily my wife looked up diskenesia on the web and found that it could become permanent.  After a few more weeks of symptoms she insisted that the doctor return me to haldol.  In a matter of days the Targive symptoms started to disappear.  I am no longer going to change my effective treatments for new drugs pushed by ill informed doctors.

column2: up all night, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have severe tnnitus ,a high pitched sound  24/7. Along with Labyrinthitis for the past 22 months. I cannot sleep because of the loud sounds .I have been on almost every drug to help me sleep. My Dr. started me on Seroquel 100mg. along with 15 mg. Flurazepam I just had 2 nights of sleep,then 2 nights of on and off sleep.I had 1 full week of no sleep at all in May,when we tried Rozerum. I was so sleep deprived I could not even stand up on my own. Being only 102 lbs. and 48 yrs. old I want something to work for me. It has been really hard on my husband and our 2 children. My Dr. says we might have to up the dose to 200mg. to sleep. I can only hope a larger dose will do it for me. It is so hard to function when you are sleep deprived. I have done vestibular rehab therapy with a physical therapist for the past 20 months.My vertigo and dizzy, nausea, and walking and normal daily life has changed drastically.Symptoms are worse with less sleep, I hate living this way, but it could be worse, so I need to try just about anything.Hypnosis didn't work either.

column2: infp76, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I use this for chronic insomnia at 100mg and have been on it about 3 years. I started at 50mg but needed a dose increase after about 1.5 years. I've noticed that 100mg still puts me to sleep but doesn't give me that "whoa" feeling when it kicks in like it used to, and also takes longer to kick in. But it still works for me when nothing else has. I tried ambien at 10mg but it took 50mg (over the course of a few hours) to barely put me to sleep for 4 hours. I also tried trazedone which had the opposite effect, and some samples of Lunesta which were too weak. Given all this I'm not even going to bother with Rozerem. NOTHING puts me to sleep and keeps me asleep like Seroquel. It has been a lifesaver. I've gained a little weight but that's because when the drowsy kicks in, hunger kicks in as well (side effect). But I'm just lazy and give in to the hunger without considering other options to curb the hunger, or consuming less fattening foods before sleep.Note to people reading this for insomnia! Most general practitioners have little/no experience with this drug, and won't feel at all comfortable prescribing it for insomnia (let alone what it's intended for). You will most likely need to see a psychiatrist for a Rx. To a psychiatrist, this drug at a low dose (~100mg which is plenty to sleep for most people) is no big deal to them. I never heard of this when it was prescribed to me so I did some searching on google. I read some horror stories with the drug (mostly weight gain) and didn't even want to take it but when it knocked me out the first night, I haven't skipped a night since. Most of the horror stories you'll find are the exception and not the rule. Talk to your psychiatrist and they will most likely confirm this.
Use it to sleep, 150mg works well for me, but i keep having to up my dose so its definitly not going to be long term...

column2: lollielox, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I was put on Seroquel to help with my anxiety and my impulsive self harm. Overall, I found that the meds did help me to curb my problem, only because it knocked me out, and I was extremely lethargic and 'zombie' like through my whole therapy with this drug. I asked my psychiatrist about this, and she simply stated: "well, you can't hurt yourself if you're not awake. So, it's doing it's job".
